At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Patrick Kane. Please go ahead.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kyle. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in EQT Corporation's Conference Call. With me today are Dave Porges, CEO; Steve Schlotterbeck, President of EQT and E&P; Phil Conti, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Randy Crawford, S
componenttext:
Thanks, Kyle. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in EQT Corporation's Conference Call. With me today are Dave Porges, CEO; Steve Schlotterbeck, President of EQT and E&P; Phil Conti, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Randy Crawford, Senior Vice President of EQT and President of Midstream and Commercial. 
This call will be replayed for a 7-day period beginning at approximately 1:30 p.m. today. The telephone number for the replay is (719) 457-0820 with a confirmation code of 4832196. The call will also be replayed for 7 days on our website. 
To remind you, the results of EQT Midstream Partners, ticker EQM; and EQTGP Holdings, ticker EQGP, are consolidated in EQT's results. Earlier this morning, there was a separate joint press release issued by EQM and EQGP. The partnership will have a joint earnings conference call at 11:30 a.m. today, which requires that we take the last question at on this call at 11:20. The dial in number for that call it if you're interested is (913) 312-9034. 
And in just a moment, Phil will summarize EQT's year-end 2015 results. Next, Steve will give a Utica update and summarize today's reserve report. And finally, Dave will provide a summary of the 2016 budget and the balance sheet implications. 
Following the prepared remarks, Dave, Phil, Randy and Steve will be available to answer your questions. 
I'd like to remind you that today's call may contain forward-looking statements. You can find factors that could cause the company's actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements listed in today's press release and under Risk Factors in EQT's Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014, as updated by any subsequent Form 10-Qs, which are on file with the SEC and also available on our website; and under Risk Factors in EQT's Form 10-K for year ended December 31, 2015, which will be filed with the SEC next week. 
Today's call may also contain certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to this morning's press release for important disclosures regarding such measures, including reconciliations to the most comparable GAAP financial measures. 
And I'd now like to turn the call over to Phil Conti.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. As you read in the press release this morning, EQT announced 2015 adjusted earnings of $0.75 per diluted share compared to $3.43 per diluted share in 2014. A high-level story for the year as well as for the fourth
componenttext:
Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. As you read in the press release this morning, EQT announced 2015 adjusted earnings of $0.75 per diluted share compared to $3.43 per diluted share in 2014. A high-level story for the year as well as for the fourth quarter was very strong volume growth in a lower commodity price environment. Notably, production volumes were 27% higher than last year, and midstream gathering volumes were up by 28%. Due to the lower commodity prices, adjusted EQT earnings, adjusted EPS and adjusted operating cash flow attributable to EQT for 2015 were all down versus 2014 by any measure although results in both years were impacted by some unusual items that should be considered when interpreting and comparing the results year-over-year. Adjusted operating cash flow attributable to EQT was $964.3 million in '15 compared to $1,424,000,000 in 2014. And I refer you to our non-GAAP reconciliations in today's release for more details. 
Results in the fourth quarter were similarly down. Fourth quarter 2015 adjusted net loss was $0.06 per diluted share. That compares to adjusted EPS of $0.97 in the fourth quarter of '14. Adjusted operating cash flow attributable to EQT was $233.9 million in the fourth quarter compared to $390 million for the fourth quarter of 2014. Production sales volume was 13% higher than the fourth quarter of '14. We also realized 12% higher gathering volumes than last year and continued low per unit operating cost. 
In the fourth quarter, we recorded a negative tax adjustment of $79.5 million to reserve certain state income tax net operating loss carryforwards that may not be utilized in a low commodity price environment. This had the impact of increasing the effective tax rate for the year. Netting up the effects of this NOL carryforward adjustment in the fourth quarter as well as the regulatory asset tax adjustment in the second quarter would have resulted in an effective tax rate for the year of closer to 15%. Although subject to many factors, including commodity prices, transactions, et cetera, we think a range of 10% to 15% is a reasonable effective tax rate range for year 2016 modeling purposes. 
Now moving onto a brief discussion of our results by business segment. I will begin my discussion with the full year results as the explanations for the full year for the most part apply for the fourth quarter as well. 
So starting with EQT Production. EQT Production achieved record production sales volume of the 603.1 Bcf equivalent for 2015, again, representing a 27% increase over 2014. As has been the case for many years now, the story in 2015 at EQT Production was the growth in sales of produced natural gas driven by sales from our Marcellus wells. 2015 was our sixth great year of more than 25% sales volume growth. However, lower average realized prices more than offset the increased sales of produced natural gas in our financial results. 
The EQT average realized price was $2.67 per Mcf equivalent for '15, and that was $1.49 or 36% lower per unit than last year. For segment reporting purposes, of that $2.67 realized by EQT Corporation, $1.74 was allocated EQT Production with the remaining $0.93 allocated to EQT Midstream. The majority of the $0.93 is for gathering, which averaged $0.74 per Mcf equivalent for the year. 
For the full year, total operating expenses at EQT Production were $1,251.6 million, excluding asset impairment charges and onetime drilling costs or 19% higher year-over-year. DD&A, SG&A and LOE were all higher, again consistent with the significant production growth although production taxes were lower for the year as a result of lower prices. Per unit LOE, including production taxes, was 25% lower year-over-year as volume increased more than expenses. 
Moving on to the midstream result. Operating income here was up 23% year-over-year, mainly as a result of increased gathering and transmission revenues, partly offset by increased operating expenses. Gathering revenues also increased by almost 27% year-over-year as a result of higher gathering volumes in 2015. Total operating expenses at midstream were $318.8 million or $41.2 million higher than 2014, excluding an impairment and the exploration of some right of way options. This increase was consistent with the growth of the midstream business. 
And then finally, our standard liquidity update. We closed the year in a great rate liquidity position, with 0 net short-term debt outstanding under EQT's $1.5 billion unsecured revolver and about $1.25 billion of cash on the balance sheet, and that excludes cash on hand at EQM and EQGP. We currently forecast $600 million to $650 million of operating cash flow for 2016 at EQT, which includes approximately $150 million of distributions to EQT from EQGP. So we are fully capable of funding our roughly $1 billion 2016 CapEx forecast, excluding EQM and EQGP with that expected operating cash flow as well as the current cash on hand. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Steve for an update on the Utica program as well as some thoughts on today's reserve release.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Phil. As Phil just said, today, I'd like to review 2 topics: the 2015 reserve report and an update on our Deep Utica program. Starting with the Utica. As you know, we turned in line our first Deep Utica well, the Scots Run591360 in July of 2015.
componenttext:
Thanks, Phil. As Phil just said, today, I'd like to review 2 topics: the 2015 reserve report and an update on our Deep Utica program. 
Starting with the Utica. As you know, we turned in line our first Deep Utica well, the Scots Run591360 in July of 2015. The well continues to produce at a consistent 30 million cubic feet per well with a steady pressure decline. The well is exceeding our previous forecast, and we now expect this well to flow at 30 million cubic feet a day until mid-April before it begin its production decline. As a result, we revised the range of our EUR estimate to between 5.1 and 5.9 Bcfe per thousand foot of lateral. As a reminder, this well has completed a lateral length of 3,221 feet. And to date, this well has produced 5.8 Bcf. 
Our second well, the padded 593066 was completed the very end of December. This well has a 5,200-foot lateral and was completed with a 29-stage frac job. After initial cleanup and the 24-hour flow test at 43 million cubic feet per day, we shut the well in for an extended reservoir pressure test and to install the permanent production facilities. On January 29, we bought the well online at a choke-restricted rate of 20 million cubic feet per day with a floating casing pressure of 8,700 psi. The initial results from the padded well appear to be in line with other Deep Utica wells in the area and are consistent with our expectations of Utica across our core focus area. 
In addition to the 2 producing wells, we spud another 2 Utica wells. The Big 190 well in Wetzel county, west Virginia has been drilled to TD, and we are now in the process of completing the 35-stage frac job. It has a 6,300-foot lateral and has an expected turn in-line date in late February or early March. 
Our fourth well, the Shipment well in Greene County, Pennsylvania is currently being top set with a planned a length of 7,000 feet. On the cost side for the Utica, we've been able to achieve significant savings on each of our wells and are ahead of our schedule to meet our target of $12.5 million to $14 million per well. Savings have been realized in all phases of the development cycle with the most significant savings coming from improved drilling efficiency. Adjusting for lateral length, the padded well cost $17.3 million, and the Big 190 cost $15.4 million. On a cost per-foot basis, we've successfully lowered our costs from $9,600 per foot for Scotts Run well to $2,800 per foot for Big 190. As a reminder, we have 2 objectives for our 2016 Utica program: one, get the cost per well down to our target range, which we expect to achieve an hour currently drilling shipment well; and two, confirm the productivity of the reservoir within our core Utica focus areas in Southwestern PA and Northern West Virginia. If we can accomplish both objectives, we expect that Utica returns in the core area will be competitive with or better than the core Marcellus, and we will work on a plan to include Utica in our future development planes. We will update you on our progress each quarter. 
Moving on to the reserve report. As you saw in our press release this morning, we announced total proved reserves of 10 TCFE, with 6.3 Tcfe of these reserves associated with wells that have already been developed. This proved developed reserves totaled 30% higher than year-end 2014 and includes 2.1 Tcfe of increases. Within that 2.1 Tcfe increase is 386 Bcfe improved developed reserves from wells that were unproved in 2014 but were ultimately drilled and completed in 2015. This is consistent with the company's history of continuing to expand its footprint and develop areas that we believe to be economic even when they do not meet the SEC's definition of proved reserves. 
Also contributing into our increased proved developed reserves is over 300 Bcfe from producing wells that are outperforming our previous forecast. Additionally, we converted 1.5 Tcfe or 25% of our 2014 PUD reserves into the proved developed category. We also cut our 5-year PUD development plan in half, which is consistent with our reduced activity in 2016. Both of these factors contributed to a 37% decrease in PUD reserves. 
Looking at just our Marcellus reserves. The average proved location considering both developed and undeveloped is 700 feet longer and has an EUR that is 1.4 Bcfe greater than the average proved Marcellus location booked in 2014. These statistics demonstrate consistently strong well performance as well as EQT's ability to continue leveraging our acreage position within our core development area, allowing us to drill longer laterals. In fact, our PUD reserve reflect 337 Bcfe of increases that is directly related to lenth extensions of previously booked undeveloped locations. These length extensions not only boost the economics of reserves of previously booked locations but also allow us to book 703 Bcfe of the new PUD locations that were previously too short to be considered economic PUDs. To further offset the effect of low pricing, EQT continue to improve our efficiency and drive development cost lower. The development cost of wells completed in 2015 was $0.83 per Mcfe versus $1.15 per Mcfe for wells completed in 2014. This 27% reduction was driven by longer laterals, drilling and completion efficiency and significant reductions in service cost, particularly on the frac side. 
Our current estimate of total resource potential is 78 Tcfe, which now includes 25 Tcfe attributed to the core of our deep Utica play. Also within that 78 Tcfe of resource potential are our probable and possible reserves. As noted in this morning's release, using SEC's required trailing 12-month pricing methodology resulted in total probable and possible reserves of 14.60 Tcfe. If you look at forward-looking prices, which are more representative of our development assumptions, our probable and possible reserves would total 35 Tcfe. Neither of those probable and possible totals includes any deep Utica well serves as we are relegating that play to other resource potential for now with the exception of the 24 Bcf of proved reserves from our 2 producing wells. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Dave.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. This morning, I would like to review our financial situation and philosophy when establishing our 2016 CapEx budget announced in December as this is our first call since that time. As Phil mentioned, we ended 2015 with well over $1 billi
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. This morning, I would like to review our financial situation and philosophy when establishing our 2016 CapEx budget announced in December as this is our first call since that time. As Phil mentioned, we ended 2015 with well over $1 billion in cash and with nothing drawn in our $1.5 billion unsecured revolver. In that context and given that we have other potential sources of cash such as in other midstream drop, we were comfortable with a CapEx estimate that was moderately higher than our operating cash flow estimate for 2016. However, we do not have any plans to significantly erode that strong liquidity position as we believe that our current conservative financial approach is appropriate for today's environment. The rest of my remarks will elaborate on that view. 
First, we're have been looking to add to our core acreage position for the past year but have not yet transacted as sellers have not fully accepted the valuation impact of low commodity prices. Ironically, even sellers expectations did begin coming more into line with current market realities, we narrowed our geographic focus to possibilities that have real consolidation benefits within the core of the core as we have referred to it. As the market continues to evolve, it seems to us reasonably likely that there will be some actual transactions in the first half of 2016. However, given our tighter focus as well as some other attributes to the current market, smaller asset transactions seem more likely than larger or whole company deals. 
Speaking of the market, let's shift to our view of the natural gas supply-demand market. You may recall that I do consider rig count to be a reasonable, if rough, leading indicator of natural gas production though some adjustments need to be made to glean any meaning from the published data. For instance, there's a longer lead time between spuds and marketable production than there used to be. Rigs are more efficient than they used to be, especially because of longer laterals and also improved completion techniques, and more natural gas production comes from drilling that the data associates with crude oil-focused activity. As an example of the latter issue that is associated with gas, we're using the published Baker Hughes data, we believe it's best to look at gas equivalent rig count. And admittedly, adjustment to try to account for this associated gas involves assuming that each oil rig behaves more as if it's 3/4 oil and 1/4 gas, but the gas equivalent rig count equals gas-directed rigs plus 0.25x oil-directed rigs. The gas equivalent rig count calculated that way was essentially flat at 700 to 800 from mid-2012 through the end of 2014, so for about 2.5 years. The gas equivalent rig count then decline by about 45% by the spring of 2015, at which point it totaled about 380 until last summer and then again declined gradually by another 10% or so. Then starting in late autumn, the gas equivalent rig count declined an additional 25-plus percent, reaching 246 last week. I recognize that only 121 of those are natural gas that exist in the side. That 121 compares to a high in Pennsylvania alone of about 117 rigs not that many years ago. So this 246  of nearly 2/3 below the last rig count of 2014 and 35% lower than it was just in August of last year. This sharp downturn in activity suggest lower future natural gas production. The question in my opinion is, when. That is, how long is that lag? At EQT, where we drill multi-well pads and long lateral wells, the lag from wells spud to turn in line or tail is 9 to 12 months. Other drillers may have some shorter or longer lags, but they all have material lags. The existence of so-called ducks, that is drilled but uncompleted wells, obviously lengthens the time lag between spud and till. Also, improved efficiencies can mean that one rig today is equivalent to 1-plus rigs of a year ago, but this is only true for some efficiencies such as longer laterals. Efficiencies such as reduced cost spacing, which also tend to accelerate production, can affect the rate volume relationship somewhat over time but mainly improve economics and, therefore, reduce the economic clearing price at which a supply equals demand. My point is to try to predict the exact timing at a production decline, but rather that this decline will occur and it is best if we position ourselves to quickly respond to a higher gas price when the time is appropriate. We believe that a strong balance sheet does this. Based on my expectations of declining supply, I am reasonably bullish on natural gas prices once we have worked off with the current inventory surplus as the current activity level is insufficient to meet demand over time. That said, increased efficiencies and a tighter focus on the core of the core have certainly decreased of the clearing price for natural gas perhaps to the mid-$3 per Mcf range down from our previous expectations of around $4. I do expect that the price will go past that clearing price to the upside eventually as we have seen in the past as the lags that have delayed the production decline emanating from reduced activity will also delay an increase in supply from a future increase activity. Given the industry leaning cost structure of our core Marcellus acreage and potentially the Utica, EQT can make excellent returns at mid-$3 gas. Still, just as we think it is important to be well positioned when the market overshoots to the downside, we will want to be similarly well positioned when the market eventually overshoots to the high side even though that high side overshoot one of our price as nearly as high as they were even a future years ago. 
In times of financial stress for our industry, we think the prudent approach is to be conservative financially. Whatever happens over the course of the rest of this year and into next year from a commodity price perspective, we believe that having a strong balance sheet and available cash will put EQT in a position of strategic advantage. This is certainly true if my macro thesis is correct. However, if the alternative theses are prices that are much lower from much longer is correct, having a strong balance sheet and available cash will also put EQT in a position of strategic advantage. From what we can see, there's no reasonably likely thesis under which our shareholders would be well served by us surrendering those advantages. 
So in summary, EQT is committed to increasing the value of your shares, and we look forward to continuing to execute in our commitment to our shareholders, and we appreciate your continued support. 
With that, I'll turn the call back over to Pat Kane.

componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question with Scott Hanold with Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question with Scott Hanold with Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Steve, if I could ask you on the deep Utica. Obviously, the first well is little better than you expected, and if you read the Math, I think you guys are projecting right somewhere around 18 Bcfe EUR. And just so I understand this right, in the total b
componenttext: So Steve, if I could ask you on the deep Utica. Obviously, the first well is little better than you expected, and if you read the Math, I think you guys are projecting right somewhere around 18 Bcfe EUR. And just so I understand this right, in the total bookings for the 2 would be 24, so does that imply the second well is -- the expectations are around 6 Bcf? Is that the correct Math?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would -- I think there's 2 adjustments you need to make. One -- or keep in mind trying to use the SEC reserve number to back in to EUR estimates. One, those are reserves not EURs, so anything produced prior to December 31, that's fairly minor for
componenttext: Well, I would -- I think there's 2 adjustments you need to make. One -- or keep in mind trying to use the SEC reserve number to back in to EUR estimates. One, those are reserves not EURs, so anything produced prior to December 31, that's fairly minor for the padded well. But it's also using the SEC definitions. So reasonable certainty, we have 2 producing wells. The padded well had almost no production data, so our reserve projections in that case tend to be pretty much on the conservative side. So I'm not sure the SEC numbers for the Utica wells really reflect very accurately our view. And we think it's too early to really comment on our view of the EUR for the second well. But I would say that it's consistent with our expectations of the Utica. It's very, very early but probably not quite as good as Scotts Run. I think the Scotts Run well will likely stand out for quite a while as an exceptional well and one that's definitely above the mean for the Utica.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So can I ask you this question, what was, I guess, from what you've seen in Scotts Run versus the padded, what made the Scotts Run that much better?
componenttext: So can I ask you this question, what was, I guess, from what you've seen in Scotts Run versus the padded, what made the Scotts Run that much better?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we know at the current time. We're doing a lot of reservoir testing and studying it pretty closely, and I don't think we have any firm conclusions. Again, we have some limited data points. We have 2 data points now. And the second data point
componenttext: I don't think we know at the current time. We're doing a lot of reservoir testing and studying it pretty closely, and I don't think we have any firm conclusions. Again, we have some limited data points. We have 2 data points now. And the second data point has such a limited history that it I think it's premature to speculate too much about the reservoir just yet. Other than to say, I think, one thing we've proven is, with the Scotts Run, clearly, there's going to be areas of the Utica that are exceptionally good. And with the cost that we've already achieved, the economics of those types of locations will be superior to how probably any of the Marcellus opportunities that we have. But we need to define where those the areas are, how big they are, how repeatable they are. And Then you're going to have lots of areas that it's going to depend a lot on completion techniques and the final cost of these wells to see how it compares to the Marcellus. I think that's going to take us some time and quite a few more wells to really define, but there's certainly going to be some areas that are exceptional.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so would I be correct in saying that, and I realize it's only the fact that we've got limited data especially on the second well. But certainly, you guys are still trying to evaluate whether or not this deep Utica well opportunity can compete with som
componenttext: And so would I be correct in saying that, and I realize it's only the fact that we've got limited data especially on the second well. But certainly, you guys are still trying to evaluate whether or not this deep Utica well opportunity can compete with some of your better Marcellus areas. Obviously, Scotts Run, you gave your indications that it has a good chance. But I guess, the second well, is it sort of put your a little bit on the sidelines yet?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, I mean, you can't oversimplify the process that we need to go through. It's a brand-new play, very limited data potentially over a fairly broad area. And I would say, our expectations always have been that there will be some areas that are
componenttext: Well, I think, I mean, you can't oversimplify the process that we need to go through. It's a brand-new play, very limited data potentially over a fairly broad area. And I would say, our expectations always have been that there will be some areas that are really, really good. I think the Scotts Run clearly demonstrates that. There's going to be some areas that take more time to figure out exactly how good they are and exactly how they stack up to the Marcellus. And there's clearly going to be areas that you could tell Utica wells, very productive Utica wells but you don't compete economically. I mean, the Utica is huge. It covers very large areas. So there's going to be areas of exceptional performance and economics, areas of competitive with the core Marcellus. And remember, that's our hurdle is comparing it to the best of our Marcellus opportunities. And there's going to be areas where it falls short. It's going to take some time to define that.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we haven't change the target, but I'm feeling pretty comfortable that our next well within that range. We saw a long way to go on it, so I think it happens, but it's looking pretty good. I'm becoming much more optimistic that we will be ultim
componenttext: Yes, I think we haven't change the target, but I'm feeling pretty comfortable that our next well within that range. We saw a long way to go on it, so I think it happens, but it's looking pretty good. I'm becoming much more optimistic that we will be ultimately at the bottom part of that range rather than the top part. It's just a little early for us to revise that range. We wanted to get in it for a well or 2 before we start updating it. But I think our confidence in the lower part of the range goes up everyday. There are still quite a few areas for improvement, and that's, I guess, that's why I'm so optimistic. We're going to be within that range and identifying numerous opportunities for future improvements. So we'll keep you up-to-date on how we're doing.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as far as, I know it's early, but as far as different parts of the play, do you expect well cost to be materially different between West Virginia and Pennsylvania once you get into that sale when you get too close to the targets?
componenttext: And as far as, I know it's early, but as far as different parts of the play, do you expect well cost to be materially different between West Virginia and Pennsylvania once you get into that sale when you get too close to the targets?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, well, the biggest driver will be depth. Across most of our acreage, the depth doesn't change a lot, so for us, it's probably won't vary that much. There are some regulatory differences between Pennsylvania and West Virginia, particularly around c
componenttext: I think, well, the biggest driver will be depth. Across most of our acreage, the depth doesn't change a lot, so for us, it's probably won't vary that much. There are some regulatory differences between Pennsylvania and West Virginia, particularly around casing and cementing designs. But they vary a little bit by state, although again, not that much. So I think cost variability should be pretty low other than depth and, of course, lateral length and number of stages.

componenttext: Yes, the shipment well is also in Greene County. I don't remember the distance from the other 2, but in the same general vicinity. And the West Virginia wells will be very dependent on the results we see from the BIG-190 well, which we, again, we're 2/3 of the way down tracking. So we should have results late February early March, which will influence our thinking about sort of where the program goes after that.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to clarify your comments, you're saying based on your initial results in the deep Utica well, it's kind of matching your expectations. And you think based on the limited data that you have, if you can get well cost into that range that it could co
componenttext: So just to clarify your comments, you're saying based on your initial results in the deep Utica well, it's kind of matching your expectations. And you think based on the limited data that you have, if you can get well cost into that range that it could compete with your Marcellus program? Obviously, a lot more drilling and completing the [indiscernible] but just wanted to get your initial read on how the program initially competes with the Marcellus?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think our thinking all along is if we can get within that range and get the results that we were hoping to get, there will be areas of Utica that are competitive with our very best Marcellus. And I think clearly, the Scotts Run, which I would repea
componenttext: Yes. I think our thinking all along is if we can get within that range and get the results that we were hoping to get, there will be areas of Utica that are competitive with our very best Marcellus. And I think clearly, the Scotts Run, which I would repeat, we don't expect the Scotts Run result to be the norm. So that's not when we factor in what we think the Utica is going to do. We're assuming something a little less productive than Scotts Run. But yes, I think our view is, if we can get within that cost range and have the productivity that we think we can get that there'll be areas that are competitive and probably some areas that will outcompete some of our best Marcellus.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Got you. And just the overall objective of this year's appraisal program, which could be 5 to 10 wells?
componenttext: Got you. Got you. And just the overall objective of this year's appraisal program, which could be 5 to 10 wells?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, as I said in my comments, we had 2 objectives. The first one and going into the year was our primary focus was to get the cost down. Since we started at around $30 million a well. We were certain that cost in that range were never going to yiel
componenttext: Well, yes, as I said in my comments, we had 2 objectives. The first one and going into the year was our primary focus was to get the cost down. Since we started at around $30 million a well. We were certain that cost in that range were never going to yield an economic project. We've gotten those cost down quite a bit faster than I had expected. So that was our primary objective, but I think we were almost there. We can't quite declare victory yet, but we are getting very, very close. The second objective was to understand of the productivity and the extent within the core of that productivity of the Utica, and that's why we have to drill a 5- to 10-well program this year and get various data appoints. And as we all know, early in new plays, there is always a lot of improvement even on the completion side. You have to get up the learning curve. So we'll make some mistakes. We'll have some -- obviously, we'll have some fantastic wells. We'll probably have some underperforming wells as we experiment with different techniques. And we have together that data and analyze it, and it's a lengthy process. So we're going to spend the year gathering data and studying it. And as we become comfortable with the implications, we'll communicate that to you.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my final question is looking at the core Marcellus program. In 2015, you drilled to about 160 Marcellus wells with an average lateral length of 5,400 feet this year. Obviously, you're doing much longer laterals, plan to do 72 wells. Can you comm
componenttext: Okay. And my final question is looking at the core Marcellus program. In 2015, you drilled to about 160 Marcellus wells with an average lateral length of 5,400 feet this year. Obviously, you're doing much longer laterals, plan to do 72 wells. Can you comment on what you're seeing in terms of well productivity for the longer laterals? Are you seeing similar EURs per thousand foot of lateral and just maybe comment on the potential for well productivity gains in '16 versus '15?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our experience has been the productivity versus lateral length is perfectly linear at least out to 10,000 feet. We've seen no dropoff in productivity per foot as we've drilled longer, which is why we think long time -- the longer, the better. So we w
componenttext: Yes. Our experience has been the productivity versus lateral length is perfectly linear at least out to 10,000 feet. We've seen no dropoff in productivity per foot as we've drilled longer, which is why we think long time -- the longer, the better. So we work really hard in our land department to put together drilling locations with the longest possible lateral. So you've seen our laterals get longer especially this year. A lot of that's driven by all the land work that goes on behind the scenes to make that happen. It hasn't been a change in our thinking about the economics of longer laterals. We've always believed longer is better.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Michael Hall with Energy Advisers.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Michael Hall with Energy Advisers.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I just wanted to talk a little bit about the big picture outlook around production. David, you walked through -- your views around the market and the big lags that you can see around laying down rigs and activity relative to production and highlig
componenttext: I guess I just wanted to talk a little bit about the big picture outlook around production. David, you walked through -- your views around the market and the big lags that you can see around laying down rigs and activity relative to production and highlighted 9- to 12-month lag you guys typically see. In that context, the reduced well count in '16 versus '15, how are you thinking about growth potential in '17, fully understanding it's premature to quantify, but just kind of high level? What are the key factors within the '16 program driving the our expectations around the year out from here?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We certainly think we'll be looking at a lower growth rate in '17 versus '16 but also think that we will be seeing some growth. And probably, I guess you could always say that the productivity at the specific wells that we drilled is going to influence wh
componenttext: We certainly think we'll be looking at a lower growth rate in '17 versus '16 but also think that we will be seeing some growth. And probably, I guess you could always say that the productivity at the specific wells that we drilled is going to influence what happens in the next year. In this case, you probably particularly say it hinges on some of the Utica even though that's not many Utica wells. But generally speaking, I think it has to be for any of the companies that you're looking at that when you see lower capital expenditure in these kind of lags that when you look at another 9 to 12 months, you're going to be seen a reduction in the growth rate. I think there's going to be folks like us where, I'd say, you'll see that real reduction in the growth rate. And I think probably a great untalked about elephant in the room, as it were, is the companies where they had a sharp reduction in capital expenditures and their growth rates going to have parentheses on it in 2017. And frankly, I think they'll have a psychologically beneficial effect on the natural gas price market, but that's still within the context of the clearing price that's a lot lower than what we would've thought maybe a couple of years back. So that won't be the case for EQT, but you will see you see a reduction in growth rate, you will for anybody who's cutting their capital expenditures. I'd happy to have anyone else here add their thoughts to that.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe the one piece of information I could provide is -- relate it might be helpful, is if we look what at our maintenance CapEx needs are to maintain a 2 Bcf a day production rate and this is all-in capital, including sufficient capital to replace the ac
componenttext: Maybe the one piece of information I could provide is -- relate it might be helpful, is if we look what at our maintenance CapEx needs are to maintain a 2 Bcf a day production rate and this is all-in capital, including sufficient capital to replace the acreage that we've developed with the program, so certainly in theory, this would be a sustainable level of drilling. We need about $700 million per year to sustain 2 Bcf a day adding some items. So would that give you more information.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. You know roughly of that $700 million, sorry to get greedy here, but how much of that is net acreage replacement relative to the drilling and completion dollars?
componenttext: That's helpful. You know roughly of that $700 million, sorry to get greedy here, but how much of that is net acreage replacement relative to the drilling and completion dollars?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The well drilling and completion is about $575 million. And then you have acreage, some capitalized overheads, G&G cost, compliance CapEx, bunch of other items to make up that difference though.
componenttext: The well drilling and completion is about $575 million. And then you have acreage, some capitalized overheads, G&G cost, compliance CapEx, bunch of other items to make up that difference though.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So why don't I for some peers for some reason, we assume they obviously -- we all try to do what's best for our shareholders but are talking about no rigs operating in 2016. And I think it's phenomenal what the industry has done with improved rig efficien
componenttext: So why don't I for some peers for some reason, we assume they obviously -- we all try to do what's best for our shareholders but are talking about no rigs operating in 2016. And I think it's phenomenal what the industry has done with improved rig efficiencies. I'm still a little dubious that you can get down to no rigs and still have your production keep going up.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. At some point, it seems that it'll give.
componenttext: Yes. At some point, it seems that it'll give.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And yet, frankly, the market seems to behave as if, of course, we can get to no rigs and volumes will keep going up.
componenttext: And yet, frankly, the market seems to behave as if, of course, we can get to no rigs and volumes will keep going up.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I always wanted to think about a little bit near term, you've got a pretty substantial quarter-on-quarter growth rate implied by the first quarter guidance. Is that more a function of fourth quarter timing of well completions, or i.e. late completions in
componenttext: I always wanted to think about a little bit near term, you've got a pretty substantial quarter-on-quarter growth rate implied by the first quarter guidance. Is that more a function of fourth quarter timing of well completions, or i.e. late completions in the fourth quarter or early completions in the first quarter or some other key variables?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's both of those reasons and really nothing more. It's really timing of when the rigs get done and the fracs get done and wells get turned online versus specific quarter-end date. So yes, we are expecting an increase of substantial growth rate in the fi
componenttext: It's both of those reasons and really nothing more. It's really timing of when the rigs get done and the fracs get done and wells get turned online versus specific quarter-end date. So yes, we are expecting an increase of substantial growth rate in the first quarter. We will be, this year, in 2016, the growth will be more concentrated in the first half of the year than in the second half. And you will see -- if you look at our backlog numbers, they came down a little bit in the fourth quarter. We expect to see a pretty substantial drop when we report the results for the first quarter in terms of stages complete bottom line.

componenttext: Okay. So the completions pace in 2016 is also then front-loaded, I would assume. But that comment, is that fair?

componenttextpreview: In terms of stages, they come on per quarter, more front-end loaded. It's just the nature of the timing of the rigs and the reduction in our capital programs, so you'll see that reflected more in the second half of the year in terms of number of stages th
componenttext: In terms of stages, they come on per quarter, more front-end loaded. It's just the nature of the timing of the rigs and the reduction in our capital programs, so you'll see that reflected more in the second half of the year in terms of number of stages that come online.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Back to Scotts Run well, I wanted to ask in terms of the increase in EUR per lateral foot. Is that simply a function of the pressures not declining as fast as you originally modeled?
componenttext: Back to Scotts Run well, I wanted to ask in terms of the increase in EUR per lateral foot. Is that simply a function of the pressures not declining as fast as you originally modeled?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's the primary driver, but it's also -- so we model that, so it's not just that the extra time it's going to take to get to pipeline pressure. It's the history matching of our reservoir models. The pressure declined that we match now indicates a
componenttext: Well, that's the primary driver, but it's also -- so we model that, so it's not just that the extra time it's going to take to get to pipeline pressure. It's the history matching of our reservoir models. The pressure declined that we match now indicates a higher potential EUR than the matches we were getting with the West data so -- but it manifests itself of slower pressure decline than we originally have modeled.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And just the progress on the cost side on the shipment well specifically, it looks like you're pretty close to hitting your original target. Is there a different completion design there? Are you still using ceramic? Or have you switched to s
componenttext: Okay, got it. And just the progress on the cost side on the shipment well specifically, it looks like you're pretty close to hitting your original target. Is there a different completion design there? Are you still using ceramic? Or have you switched to sand?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We switched the sand on the padded well, so only the -- at the current time, our plans are only the Scotts Run who have ceramic. Our reservoir engineering analysis suggest that we're not seeing any impacts from switching to sand. We're going to monitor th
componenttext: We switched the sand on the padded well, so only the -- at the current time, our plans are only the Scotts Run who have ceramic. Our reservoir engineering analysis suggest that we're not seeing any impacts from switching to sand. We're going to monitor that, and it's clearly if it would indicate that ceramic would drive a meaningful change in well performance, we would switch back and at least experiment more with it. But for now, we're going with sand for this and all future wells.

componenttext: Just on the last question, you switched to sand in the padded well. I guess I'm just curious on the next 2 or I guess 5 that will be competed this year or sand concentration, water volumes and/or stage clusters phasing changing in any of those next 5 wells?

componenttext: Well, that's hard to answer because we will decide as we gather data and have to commit to certain completion designs. I think for now generally speaking, it's a very general comment, we're going to try to not change too many variables at once. So I think the completion designs most likely remain very similar unless the data that comes back is indicating that there's something that we do want to change and gather data on. So again, I'm expecting not a lot of changes, but that said, I would expect that we will be tweaking a few things over the course of the next several wells.

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I'm curious, switching gears in Marcellus. Can you guys give any detail regarding what do you think the optimal spacing throughout your core Marcellus? And does this change as you move from Southwest PA dry into the wet West Virginia window?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, actually, we don't see a lot of change driven by drivers as wet. We do see some differences in optimum spacing driven more by clay content in the rock. And our spacing varies from as close as 500 feet in certain areas to as wide as 1,000. I think ou
componenttext: Well, actually, we don't see a lot of change driven by drivers as wet. We do see some differences in optimum spacing driven more by clay content in the rock. And our spacing varies from as close as 500 feet in certain areas to as wide as 1,000. I think our average right now is running around 700 feet. So it varies by geographic location and by geology. But 500 to 750 are probably the 2 most common spacing with a few areas at 1,000.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll just keep looking. And I think this is what happens in a down market is less sellers. The sellers have a more difficult time adapting to lower valuations than the buyers do. I don't think that's unique in oil and gas. I think you probably see that r
componenttext: We'll just keep looking. And I think this is what happens in a down market is less sellers. The sellers have a more difficult time adapting to lower valuations than the buyers do. I don't think that's unique in oil and gas. I think you probably see that real estate if you see that many number -- I'm guessing that the Houston real estate market is probably exhibiting some of the same characteristics. That's just I think what happens. The comment on the other bigger deals is, as values drop, I think the companies that sell has strategic reasons for wanting to sell. And at that point, they probably rather sell smaller packages rather than larger packages because they don't like the values that kind of hoping for things to improve. And as we focus more and more on the core of the core, it just isn't the case. I mean, as an example, there are no, I think it's fair to say, there are no publicly-traded companies where we'd say all of their properties are in what for us is the core of the core. It just doesn't exist. And then, of course, when you look at the financially troubled ones, this just a whole different cuttlefish. You can't really go in and buy those because the debt is trading at way under par, and it just doesn't work for a company like us to go in and execute that. So I think all of those things conspire to restrict the number of opportunities for transactions that makes sense for both buyer and seller.

componenttext: That makes sense. The successes in the Utica make you more introspective or introspective or whether it makes you more considerate just developing what you have for this it increased the case for broader and stricter consolidation?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say success in the Utica, I mean the one obvious advantage I'd say at face value is greatly expands our economic inventory, which might take you think consolidation is -- becomes less interesting. I think one of the big drivers in consolidation fo
componenttext: I would say success in the Utica, I mean the one obvious advantage I'd say at face value is greatly expands our economic inventory, which might take you think consolidation is -- becomes less interesting. I think one of the big drivers in consolidation for us though is the enhancement inefficiencies you get with synergies and consolidation that will apply regardless of whether the Utica. And if the Utica applies you because a longer lateral roles, more wells per pad, more efficient midstream system design. So all of those values are incremental value exists regardless of what happens within Utica. So I think there's still a compelling case for consolidation given how fragmented the Northeast natural gas plays are that there's definitely a lot of value add in having bigger more contiguous acreage positions.

Good day, and welcome to the EQT Corporation Year-End Earnings Call. Today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Patrick Kane. Please go ahead.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kyle. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in EQT Corporation's Conference Call. With me today are Dave Porges, CEO; Steve Schlotterbeck, President of EQT and E&P; Phil Conti, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Randy Crawford, S
componenttext:
Thanks, Kyle. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in EQT Corporation's Conference Call. With me today are Dave Porges, CEO; Steve Schlotterbeck, President of EQT and E&P; Phil Conti, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Randy Crawford, Senior Vice President of EQT and President of Midstream and Commercial. 
This call will be replayed for a 7-day period beginning at approximately 1:30 p.m. today. The telephone number for the replay is (719) 457-0820 with a confirmation code of 4832196. The call will also be replayed for 7 days on our website. 
To remind you, the results of EQT Midstream Partners, ticker EQM; and EQTGP Holdings, ticker EQGP, are consolidated in EQT's results. Earlier this morning, there was a separate joint press release issued by EQM and EQGP. The partnership will have a joint earnings conference call at 11:30 a.m. today, which requires that we take the last question on this call at 11:20. The dial-in number for that call, if you're interested, is (913) 312-9034. 
In just a moment, Phil will summarize EQT's year-end 2015 results. Next, Steve will give a Utica update and summarize today's reserve report. And finally, Dave will provide a summary of the 2016 budget and the balance sheet implications. 
Following the prepared remarks, Dave, Phil, Randy and Steve will be available to answer your questions. 
I'd like to remind you that today's call may contain forward-looking statements. You can find factors that could cause the company's actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements listed in today's press release and under Risk Factors in EQT's Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014, as updated by any subsequent Form 10-Qs, which are on file at the SEC and also available on our website; and under Risk Factors in EQT's Form 10-K for year ended December 31, 2015, which will be filed with the SEC next week. 
Today's call may also contain certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to this morning's press release for important disclosures regarding such measures, including reconciliations to the most comparable GAAP financial measures. 
And I'd now like to turn the call over to Phil Conti.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. As you read in the press release this morning, EQT announced 2015 adjusted earnings of $0.75 per diluted share compared to $3.43 per diluted share in 2014. A high-level story for the year as well as for the fourth
componenttext:
Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. As you read in the press release this morning, EQT announced 2015 adjusted earnings of $0.75 per diluted share compared to $3.43 per diluted share in 2014. A high-level story for the year as well as for the fourth quarter was very strong volume growth in a lower commodity price environment. Notably, production volumes were 27% higher than last year, and midstream gathering volumes were up by 28%. Due to the lower commodity prices, adjusted EQT earnings, adjusted EPS and adjusted operating cash flow attributable to EQT for 2015 were all down versus 2014 by any measure, although results in both years were impacted by some unusual items that should be considered when interpreting and comparing the results year-over-year. Adjusted operating cash flow attributable to EQT was $964.3 million in '15 compared to $1,424,000,000 in 2014. And I refer you to our non-GAAP reconciliations in today's release for more details. 
Results in the fourth quarter were similarly down. Fourth quarter 2015 adjusted net loss was $0.06 per diluted share. That compares to adjusted EPS of $0.97 in the fourth quarter of '14. Adjusted operating cash flow attributable to EQT was $233.9 million in the fourth quarter compared to $390 million for the fourth quarter of 2014. Production sales volume was 13% higher than the fourth quarter of '14. We also realized 12% higher gathering volumes than last year and continued low per unit operating cost. 
In the fourth quarter, we recorded a negative tax adjustment of $79.5 million to reserve certain state income tax net operating loss carryforwards that may not be utilized in a low commodity price environment. This had the impact of increasing the effective tax rate for the year. Netting up the effects of this NOL carryforward adjustment in the fourth quarter as well as the regulatory asset tax adjustment in the second quarter would have resulted in an effective tax rate for the year of closer to 15%. Although subject to many factors, including commodity prices, transactions, et cetera, we think a range of 10% to 15% is a reasonable effective tax rate range for year 2016 modeling purposes. 
Now moving onto a brief discussion of results by business segment. I will limit my discussion to the full year results as the explanations for the full year, for the most part, apply to the fourth quarter as well. 
So starting with EQT Production. EQT Production achieved record production sales volume of 603.1 Bcf equivalent for 2015, again representing a 27% increase over 2014. As has been the case for many years now, the story in 2015 at EQT Production was the growth in sales of produced natural gas driven by sales from our Marcellus wells. 2015 was our sixth great year of more than 25% sales volume growth. However, lower average realized prices more than offset the increased sales of produced natural gas in our financial results. 
The EQT average realized price was $2.67 per Mcf equivalent for '15, and that was $1.49 or 36% lower per unit than last year. For segment reporting purposes, of that $2.67 realized by EQT Corporation, $1.74 was allocated to EQT Production with the remaining $0.93 allocated to EQT Midstream. The majority of the $0.93 is for gathering, which averaged $0.74 per Mcf equivalent for the year. 
For the full year, total operating expenses at EQT Production were $1,251,600,000, excluding asset impairment charges and onetime drilling costs or 19% higher year-over-year. DD&A, SG&A and LOE were all higher, again consistent with the significant production growth, although production taxes were lower for the year as a result of lower prices. Per unit LOE, including production taxes, was 25% lower year-over-year, as volume increased more than expenses. 
Moving on to the midstream result. Operating income here was up 23% year-over-year, mainly as a result of increased gathering and transmission revenues, partly offset by increased operating expenses. Gathering revenues also increased by almost 27% year-over-year as a result of higher gathered volumes in 2015. Total operating expenses at midstream were $318.8 million or $41.2 million higher than 2014, excluding an impairment and the exploration of some right-of-way options. This increase was consistent with the growth of the midstream business. 
And then finally, our standard liquidity update. We closed the year in a great liquidity position, with 0 net short-term debt outstanding under EQT's $1.5 billion unsecured revolver and about $1.25 billion of cash on the balance sheet, and that excludes cash on hand at EQM and EQGP. We currently forecast $600 million to $650 million of operating cash flow for 2016 at EQT, which includes approximately $150 million of distributions to EQT from EQGP. So we are fully capable of funding our roughly $1 billion 2016 CapEx forecast, excluding EQM and EQGP with that expected operating cash flow as well as the current cash on hand. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Steve for an update on the Utica program as well as some thoughts on today's reserve release.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Phil. As Phil just said, today, I'd like to review 2 topics: The 2015 reserve report and an update on our deep Utica program. Starting with the Utica. As you know, we turned in line our first deep Utica well, the Scotts Run 591360, in July of 20
componenttext:
Thanks, Phil. As Phil just said, today, I'd like to review 2 topics: The 2015 reserve report and an update on our deep Utica program. 
Starting with the Utica. As you know, we turned in line our first deep Utica well, the Scotts Run 591360, in July of 2015. The well continues to produce at a consistent 30 million cubic feet per well with a steady pressure decline. The well is exceeding our previous forecast, and we now expect this well to flow at 30 million cubic feet a day until mid-April before it begin its production decline. As a result, we've revised the range of our EUR estimate to between 5.1 and 5.9 Bcfe per thousand foot of lateral. As a reminder, this well has a completed lateral length of 3,221 feet. And to date, this well has produced 5.8 Bcf. 
Our second well, the padded 593066 was completed at the very end of December. This well has a 5,200-foot lateral and was completed with a 29-stage frac job. After initial cleanup and the 24-hour flow test at 43 million cubic feet per day, we shut the well in for an extended reservoir pressure test and to install the permanent production facilities. On January 29, we bought the well online at a choke-restricted rate of 20 million cubic feet per day with a floating casing pressure of 8,700 psi. The initial results from the padded well appeared to be in line with other deep Utica wells in the area and are consistent with our expectations of the Utica across our core focus area. 
In addition to the 2 producing wells, we spud another 2 Utica wells. The Big 190 well in Wetzel County, West Virginia has been drilled to TD, and we are now in the process of completing the 35-stage frac job. It has a 6,300-foot lateral and has an expected turn in-line date in late February or early March. 
Our fourth well, the Shipment well in Greene County, Pennsylvania is currently being top set with a planned lateral length of 7,000 feet. On the cost side for the Utica, we've been able to achieve significant savings on each of our wells and are ahead of our schedule to meet our target of $12.5 million to $14 million per well. Savings have been realized in all phases of the development cycle with the most significant savings coming from improved drilling efficiency. Adjusting for lateral length, the padded well cost $17.3 million, and the Big 190 cost $15.4 million. On a cost-per-foot basis, we've successfully lowered our costs from $9,600 per foot for the Scotts Run well to $2,800 per foot for Big 190. As a reminder, we have 2 objectives for our 2016 Utica program: One, get the cost per well down to our target range, which we expect to achieve on our currently drilling shipment well; and two, confirm the productivity of the reservoir within our core Utica focus areas in Southwestern PA and Northern West Virginia. If we can accomplish both objectives, we expect that Utica returns in the core area will be competitive with or better than the core Marcellus, and we will work on a plan to include Utica in our future development plans. We will update you on our progress each quarter. 
Moving on to the reserves report. As you saw in our press release this morning, we announced total proved reserves of 10 Tcfe, with 6.3 Tcfe of these reserves associated with wells that have already been developed. This proved developed reserves totals 30% higher than year-end 2014 and includes 2.1 Tcfe of increases. Within that 2.1 Tcfe increase is 386 Bcfe improved developed reserves from wells that were unproved in 2014, but were ultimately drilled and completed in 2015. This is consistent with the company's history of continuing to expand its footprint and develop areas that we believe to be economic, even when they do not meet the SEC's definition of proved reserves. 
Also contributing to our increased proved developed reserves is over 300 Bcfe from producing wells that are outperforming our previous forecast. Additionally, we converted 1.5 Tcfe or 25% of our 2014 PUD reserves into the proved developed category. We also cut our 5-year PUD development plan in half, which is consistent with our reduced activity in 2016. Both of these factors contributed to a 37% decrease in PUD reserves. 
Looking at just our Marcellus reserves. The average proved location considering both developed and undeveloped is 700 feet longer and has an EUR that is 1.4 Bcfe greater than the average proved Marcellus location booked in 2014. These statistics demonstrate consistently strong well performance as well as EQT's ability to continue leveraging our acreage position within our core development area, allowing us to drill longer laterals. In fact, our PUD reserves reflect 337 Bcfe of increases that is directly related to lenth extensions of previously booked undeveloped locations. These length extensions not only boost the economics and reserves of previously booked locations, but also allowed us to book 703 Bcfe of new PUD locations that were previously too short to be considered economic PUDs. To further offset the effect of low pricing, EQT continue to improve our efficiency and drive development cost lower. The development cost of wells completed in 2015 was $0.83 per Mcfe versus $1.15 per Mcfe for wells completed in 2014. This 27% reduction was driven by longer laterals, [indiscernible] drilling and completion efficiency and significant reductions in service costs, particularly on the frac side. 
Our current estimate of total resource potential is 78 Tcfe, which now includes 25 Tcfe attributed to the core of our deep Utica play. Also within that 78 Tcfe of resource potential are our probable and possible reserves. As noted in this morning's release, using the SEC's required trailing 12-month pricing methodology resulted in total probable and possible reserves of 14.6 Tcfe. If you look at forward-looking prices, which are more representative of our development assumptions, our probable and possible reserves would total 35 Tcfe. Neither of those probable and possible totals includes any deep Utica reserves as we are relegating that play to other resource potential for now with the exception of the 24 Bcf of proved reserves from our 2 producing wells. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Dave.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. This morning, I would like to review our financial situation and philosophy when establishing our 2016 CapEx budget announced in December, as this is our first call since that time. As Phil mentioned, we ended 2015 with well over $1 bill
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. This morning, I would like to review our financial situation and philosophy when establishing our 2016 CapEx budget announced in December, as this is our first call since that time. As Phil mentioned, we ended 2015 with well over $1 billion in cash and with nothing drawn in our $1.5 billion unsecured revolver. In that context and given that we have other potential sources of cash such as another midstream drop, we were comfortable with the CapEx estimate that was moderately higher than our operating cash flow estimate for 2016. However, we do not have any plans to significantly erode that strong liquidity position as we believe that our current conservative financial approach is appropriate for today's environment. The rest of my remarks will elaborate on that view. 
First, we're have been looking to add to our core acreage position for the past year, but have not yet transacted, as sellers have not fully accepted the valuation impact of low commodity prices. Ironically, even if sellers' expectations did begin coming more into line with current market realities, we narrowed our geographic focus to possibilities that have real consolidation benefits within the core of the core as we have referred to it. As the market continues to evolve, it seems to us reasonably likely that there will be some actual transactions in the first half of 2016. However, given our tighter focus as well as some other attributes to the current market, smaller asset transactions seem more likely than larger or whole company deals. 
Speaking of the market, let's shift to our view of the natural gas supply-demand market. You may recall that I do consider rig count to be a reasonable, if rough, leading indicator of natural gas production, though some adjustments need to be made to glean any meaning from the published data. For instance, there's a longer lead time between spuds and marketable production than there used to be. Rigs are more efficient than they used to be, especially because of longer laterals and also improved completion techniques, and more natural gas production comes from drilling that the data associates with crude oil-focused activity. As an example of the latter issue that is associated to gas, when using the published Baker Hughes data, we believe it's best to look at gas equivalent rig count. And admittedly, simplistic adjustment to try to account for this associated gas involves assuming that each oil rig behaves more as if it is 3/4 oil and 1/4 gas, that the gas equivalent rig count equals gas-directed rigs plus 0.25x oil-directed rigs. The gas equivalent rig count calculated that way was essentially flat at 700 to 800 from mid-2012 through the end of 2014, so for about 2.5 years. The gas equivalent rig count then declined by about 45% by the spring of 2015, at which point it plateaued at about 380 until last summer and then again declined gradually by another 10% or so. Then starting in late autumn, the gas equivalent rig count declined an additional 25%-plus, reaching 246 last week. I recognize that only 121 of those are natural gas rigs. As an aside, that 121 compares to a high in Pennsylvania alone of about 117 rigs not that many years ago. So this 246 is nearly 2/3 below the last rig count of 2014 and 35% lower than it was just in August of last year. This sharp downturn in activity suggests lower future natural gas production. The question in my opinion is, when. That is, how long is that lag? At EQT, where we drill multi-well pads and long lateral wells, the lag from wells spud to turn in line or till is 9 to 12 months. Other drillers may have some shorter or longer lags, but they all have material lags. The existence of so-called ducks, that is drilled, but uncompleted wells, obviously lengthens the time lag between spud and till. Also improved efficiencies can mean that one rig today is equivalent to 1-plus rigs of a year ago, but this is only true for some efficiencies such as longer laterals. Efficiencies such as reduced cost spacing, which also tend to accelerate production, can affect the rate volume relationship somewhat over time, but mainly improve economics and, therefore, reduce the economic clearing price, at which supply equals demand. My point is to try to predict the exact timing of the production decline, but rather that this decline will occur, and it is best if we position ourselves to quickly respond to a higher gas price when the time is appropriate. We believe that a strong balance sheet does this. Based on my expectations of declining supply, I am reasonably bullish on natural gas prices once we have worked off with the current inventory surplus, as the current activity level is insufficient to meet demand over time. That said, increased efficiencies and a tighter focus on the core of the core have certainly decreased the clearing price for natural gas perhaps to the mid-$3 per Mcf range down from our previous expectations of around $4. I do expect that the price will go past that clearing price to the upside eventually, as we have seen in the past, as the lags that have delayed the production decline emanating from reduced activity will also delay an increase in supply from a future increased activity. Given the industry leaning cost structure of our core Marcellus acreage and potentially the Utica, EQT can make excellent returns at mid-$3 gas. Still, just as we think it is important to be well positioned when the market overshoots to the downside, we will want to be similarly well positioned when the market eventually overshoots to the high side, even though that high side overshoot won't involve prices nearly as high as they were even a few short years ago. 
In times of financial stress for our industry, we think the prudent approach is to be conservative financially. Whatever happens over the course of the rest of this year and into next year from a commodity price perspective, we believe that having a strong balance sheet and available cash will put EQT in a position of strategic advantage. This is certainly true if my macro thesis is correct. However, if the alternative theses are prices that are much lower from much longer is correct, having a strong balance sheet and available cash will also put EQT in a position of strategic advantage. From what we can see, there's no reasonably likely thesis under which our shareholders would be well served by us surrendering those advantages. 
So in summary, EQT is committed to increasing the value of your shares, and we look forward to continuing to execute on our commitment to our shareholders, and we appreciate your continued support. 
With that, I'll turn the call back over to Pat Kane.
