headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We just keep looking. And I think this is what happens in a down market is the sellers. The sellers have a more difficult time adapting to lower valuations than the buyers do. I mean, I don't think that's unique in oil and gas. I think you probably see th
componenttext: We just keep looking. And I think this is what happens in a down market is the sellers. The sellers have a more difficult time adapting to lower valuations than the buyers do. I mean, I don't think that's unique in oil and gas. I think you probably see that in real estate, if you see that in many number of places. I'm guessing that the Houston real estate market is probably exhibiting some of those same characteristics. That's just, I think, what happens. The comment on the other bigger deals is, as values drop, I think the companies that sell have strategic reasons for wanting to sell. And at that point, they probably rather sell smaller packages rather than larger packages because they don't like the values they kind of hoping for things to improve. And as we focus more and more on the core of the core, it just isn't the case. I mean, just as an example, there are no -- I think it's fair to say, there are no publicly-traded companies where we'd say all of their properties are in what, for us, is the core of the core. It just doesn't exist. And then, of course, when you look at the financially troubled ones, they're just a whole different kettle of fish. You really can't go in and buy those, because the debt is trading it way under par, and it just doesn't work for a company like us to go in and execute that. So I just think all of those things conspire to restrict the number of opportunities for transactions that makes sense for both buyer and seller.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I would say success in the Utica -- I mean, the one obvious advantage at face value is it greatly expands our economic inventory, which might take you think consolidation is -- becomes less interesting. I think one of the big drivers in consolidat
componenttext: I mean, I would say success in the Utica -- I mean, the one obvious advantage at face value is it greatly expands our economic inventory, which might take you think consolidation is -- becomes less interesting. I think one of the big drivers in consolidation for us, though, is the enhancement inefficiencies you get with synergies from consolidation. They will apply regardless of whether the Utica works. And if the Utica works applies to the Utica, so longer lateral, more wells per pad, more efficient midstream system design. So all of those values are incremental value exists regardless of what happens within Utica. So I think there's still a compelling case for consolidation given how fragmented the Northeast natural gas plays are that there's definitely a lot of value add in having bigger more contiguous acreage positions.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the EQT Corporation First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Pat Kane, Chief Investor Relations Officer.
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the EQT Corporation First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Pat Kane, Chief Investor Relations Officer. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Adam. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in EQT Corporation's Conference Call. With me today are Dave Porges, Chief Executive Officer; Steve Schlotterbeck, President of EQT and President of Exploration and Production; Randy
componenttext:
Thanks, Adam. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in EQT Corporation's Conference Call. 
With me today are Dave Porges, Chief Executive Officer; Steve Schlotterbeck, President of EQT and President of Exploration and Production; Randy Crawford, Senior Vice President of EQT and President of Midstream and Commercial; and Rob McNally, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
This call would be replayed for a 7-day period beginning at approximately 1:30 p.m. Eastern today. The telephone number for the replay is (201) 612-7415. The confirmation code is 13634047. The call will also be replayed for 7 days on our website. 
To remind you, the results of EQT Midstream Partners, ticker EQM; and EQGP Holdings, ticker EQGP, are consolidated in EQT's results. Earlier this morning, there was a separate joint press release issued by EQM and EQGP. The partnerships will have a joint earnings conference call at 10:30 a.m. today, which requires that we take the last question at 11:20 this morning. The dial-in number for that call is (201) 689-7817. 
In a moment, Rob will summarize EQT's first quarter 2016 results. Next, Steve will give a Utica update. And finally, David will discuss certain market and strategic matters. Following the prepared remarks, David, Steve, Randy and Rob will all be available to answer your questions. 
But first, I'd like to remind you that today's call may contain forward-looking statements. You can find factors that could cause the company's actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements listed in today's press release and other risk factors in EQT's Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015, as updated by any subsequent Form 10-Qs, which are on file with the SEC and available on our website. 
Today's call may also contain certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to this morning's press release for important disclosures regarding such measures, including reconciliations of most comparable GAAP financial measures. 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Robert McNally.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pat. Before we begin the Q1 result, I want to review changes to our press reconciliation and production segment page. Historically, we presented the cost of gathering and transporting are gas as revenue deductions on the price reconciliation in
componenttext:
Thank you, Pat. Before we begin the Q1 result, I want to review changes to our press reconciliation and production segment page. Historically, we presented the cost of gathering and transporting are gas as revenue deductions on the price reconciliation in production segment page. Starting today, gathering, transmission and processing costs are not reported as expenses on the production segment page. The exception is the transportation charges for capacity not used to transport EQT produced gas, which is either resold or used to transport purchased gas by our marketing group is still presented as a revenue offset in accordance with GAAP. The new net marketing services line on the production segment page includes these costs as well as the related recoveries, both of which are now excluded from the price reconciliation. Previously, this capacity cost, which were $0.23 per Mcf for the first quarter of 2016, were reported as a third-party gathering and transmission cost on the price reconciliation; while the marketing recoveries, which were $0.26 per Mcf this quarter were presented as a component of recoveries included in the average differential. The main change to guidance that you will see is that our differential guidance went from negative $0.40 to $0.50 per Mcf for 2016 to negative $0.60 to $0.70 per Mcf. Offsetting this change to reported differential is a change in our guidance to third-party gathering and transmission expense from $0.50 per Mcf for the year to $0.30 per Mcf. So netting these 2 charges, necessitated by the change in reporting format, is effectively a reiteration of our previous guidance. 
We posted the historic price reconciliation for the first quarter and the 2015 results by quarter using the new format on our website. Finally, we have also posted our updated 2016 guidance conforming to the new format. 
Now for an update on the remaining drop-down. We are currently working through the internal process, which includes all the necessary accounting, legal and commercial work. We expect the drop-down to occur in the second half of the year. As we've mentioned in the past, there's about $40 million of EBITDA to be dropped down and expect the value to be up to $300 million. As Pat mention, EQGP Holdings and EQT Midstream Partners results are consolidated in EQT Corporation's results. In this morning's release, we added a table for that calculation of net income attributable to noncontrolling interest. EQT recorded $82.8 million of net income attributable to noncontrolling interest in the first quarter of 2016 as compared to $47.7 million in the first quarter of 2015. We currently forecast $77 million of net income attributable to noncontrolling interest for the second quarter of 2016 and $320 million for the full year assuming the midpoint of EQM's guidance. 
I will now provide a brief overview of the first quarter results. As you read in the press release this morning, EQT announced first quarter 2016 adjusted earnings per diluted share of $0.07 compared to $1.07 in the first quarter of 2015. Adjusted operating cash flow attributable to EQT decreased to $156 million as compared to $218.6 million in the first quarter of 2015. The high level in history for the first quarter was strong volume growth and a lower commodity price environment with another very solid operational quarter, including record produce natural gas sales and record gathering volumes of midstream. With the exception of $3.8 million restructuring charge, the first quarter was very straightforward, so I'll keep my remarks fairly brief. 
The story at EQT Production continues to be the growth in sales of produced natural gas. Production sales volume of 179.9 Bcfe in the recently completed quarter was 24% higher than the first quarter of 2015 and 16% higher than the fourth quarter of 2015. As discussed, the lower average realized price more than offset the volume growth. The realized price was $2.63 per Mcfe compared to $4.06 per Mcfe in the first quarter of last year. You'll find the detailed components of price in the tables in this morning's press release. 
Net marketing services revenue totaled $4.6 million in the first quarter of 2016, $8.6 million lower than the same quarter last year due to incremental capacity cost in the current quarter and colder weather in 2015. Total operating expenses at EQT Production were $489.3 million or 7% higher quarter-over-quarter. DD&A, gathering, transmission and processing expenses were all higher, consistent with the significant production growth although production taxes were lower for the quarter as a result of lower prices. 
Moving on to Midstream results. Operating income here was $141.9 million, 9% higher than the first quarter of 2015. Operating revenue was $224.7 million, $16.5 million in the first quarter of last year as a result of higher Marcellus volumes. Total operating expenses were $82.9 million, $4.4 million higher quarter-over-quarter as a result of our continuing growth in the Midstream business. 
And then finally, our standard liquidity update. We closed the quarter in a great liquidity position with 0 net short-term debt outstanding under EQT's $1.5 billion unsecured revolver and about $1.6 billion of cash on the balance sheet, which is clearly cash on hand at EQM and EQGP. We currently forecast $600 million to $650 million at operating cash flow for 2016 at EQT, which includes approximately $150 million of distributions to EQT from EQGP. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Steve.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rob. My focus today is to provide an update on our deep Utica program. Our 2 objectives for 2016 are to get our cost per well down to our target range of between $12.5 million and $14 million per well and to achieve consistent well results in l
componenttext:
Thank you, Rob. My focus today is to provide an update on our deep Utica program. Our 2 objectives for 2016 are to get our cost per well down to our target range of between $12.5 million and $14 million per well and to achieve consistent well results in line with the median of wells drilled into deep Utica well by EQT and our peers so far. 
For the Utica to compete with capital with Marcellus, we're targeting EURs approximately 75% higher than our core Marcellus wells. The higher EUR per well, combined with the higher percentage of the EU are being produced in the first few years and lower expected gathering compression cost, should provide returns competitive with the Marcellus. We currently have 3 wells producing, the Scotts Run and padded wells in Greene County, Pennsylvania and the BIG-190 well in Wetzel County, West Virginia. This Scotts Run well began declining at the end of March after producing at a flat rate of 30 million cubic feet per day since July of 2015, which was a total of 244 days. The decline is in line with our expectations, and our EUR estimate for this well is currently 20 Bcf or approximately 6 Bcf per 1,000 foot of lateral. The results of the padded and Big 190 wells were not as strong as our Scotts Run well or in line with what we are seeing from other wells in the area. It is too early to calculate an EUR for these 2 wells. 
The shipment well was spud in January and is currently being fracked while the West Run well was spud in April. After West Run, we plan to move back to West Virginia to drill another well in Wetzel County, probably be called the Big 177. We used ceramic [indiscernible] on the Scotts Run and achieved superior results compared to the padded and BIG-190 wells, which used sand as the profit. It is not clear that the prop and difference explains the result, but we decided to use ceramic prop in the next 3 completions, including the shipment, to determine that the prop and type has an impact on well productivity. The good news is, we have negotiated a 40% reduction in the price of ceramic profit since the Scotts Run well. For a typical 5,400-foot lateral, the incremental cost of using ceramics versus sand is now $1.4 million per well compared to about $2.5 million incrementally at the time we drilled the Scotts Run. 
On the cost side, we continue to see significant improvement. Drilling cost continue to come down as we gain experience and improve the techniques and equipment used to drill these wells. On the completion side, we will be testing the plug technology for the first time on the shipment well. We estimate that this technology will save us an additional $700,000 per well if successful. Our team continues to safely reduce the cost of these wells and is confident we can achieve our target well cost even with ceramic prop. We will continue to provide quarterly updates on our progress on the Deep Utica, and I'll now turn the call over to Dave.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. I would like to briefly provide 2 updates and 1 other comment on today's call. The first update is to my comments in our February call regarding rig count as a leading indicator of production. At that time, there were 246 gas equivalent
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. I would like to briefly provide 2 updates and 1 other comment on today's call. The first update is to my comments in our February call regarding rig count as a leading indicator of production. At that time, there were 246 gas equivalent rigs, down from the stable level of 700 to 800 that prevailed from about mid-2012 through the end of 2014. Since that February call, the gas equivalent rig count declined by another 29% to 174 gas equivalent rigs today. This means we are now down 57% in the past year and 76% since the end of 2014. We are beginning to see what appear to be some signs of a supply reduction as a pro-U.S. gas production is about 2 Bcf per day lower than the February peak. While those 2014 rig count probably represented far too much development activity, the plateauing and beginning of a decline in production suggest that our thesis of higher future natural gas prices still looks just as solid, even though we confess that the timing of any meaningful price increases continues to be uncertain. 
Given our capital strength and the fact that we have not had to make dramatic reductions in staff, we continue to be well positioned comparatively to adjusted development plans should higher prices materialize. I do personally continue to believe that the eventual price increase will likely eventually overshoot the equilibrium price necessarily to balance supply with demand, but that just means we will have to be as disciplined in a more constructive economic environment as we have been in the current less-than-constructive economic environment. 
On a related update, we continue to look to add to our core acreage position but have not yet announced any transactions. The good news is that there are many high-quality asset packages being marketed in our core focus area. Along those lines, so that we do not have to break with our practice of not commenting on specific transactions, we wanted to provide some insight into the types of assets that we are examining. If you look at our website, for a hard copy of our most recent investment presentations, you will see a pretty clearly delineated version of our core area, all of which is in the southwestern portion of the Marcellus play. If you become aware of opportunities that are largely or entirely within our core, you can safely assume that we are looking or have looked at the opportunity. You can equally safely assume that we are not looking at and interested at looking at opportunities that lie outside our core area, again as defined by that rectangle in our current investor presentation. 
To expand on that somewhat, we further look closely at the number of drilling locations and potential feed of 10 [ph] those locations that represent a combination of EQT's existing acreage and development opportunities and those provided by the target. True synergies, if you will. My final comment pertains to an area of financial risk that I've focused on early in my time at EQT, my philosophical objection to shareholders barring the investment risk of employees portfolios via defined-benefit pension plans. The pension benefit obligation was about $150 million when I arrived at EQT, those many years ago, and was forecast to be multiples higher than that within a decade. As a result, I wanted to reduce the extent of the associated investment risk. We set about strengthening the plan over the years, and as a result, we were able to apply for and just recently received approval to finally terminate the remaining vestiges of the plan altogether. There will be a modest charge recorded possibly as soon as the second quarter, but we will have finally brought that obligation and the risk associated with it down to 0. 
In summary, EQT is committed to increasing the value of your shares. We look forward to continuing to execute on our commitment to our shareholders and appreciate your continued support. 
And with that, I'd like to turn the call back over to Pat Kane.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: With more production history on the Scotts Run, Utica well, how are you thinking about drainage and reconciling the EUR estimates to some of the gas in place estimates out there?
componenttext: With more production history on the Scotts Run, Utica well, how are you thinking about drainage and reconciling the EUR estimates to some of the gas in place estimates out there?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phil, this is Steve. I think we're still exploring that, so it is still a fairly anomalous well in terms of how productive it's been. So clearly, there's really 2 areas of focus, one is the size of the drainage area size or the size of the box that we're
componenttext: Phil, this is Steve. I think we're still exploring that, so it is still a fairly anomalous well in terms of how productive it's been. So clearly, there's really 2 areas of focus, one is the size of the drainage area size or the size of the box that we're drawing from. Since it's a reservoir we don't have a lot of experience with yet, I think there's still a lot of uncertainty about what the right drainage area is. And then there's still some questions about basically the density of the gas and the reservoir, so how much can fit inside a given box at these fairly extreme pressures we're dealing with. So without getting too technical, the behavior of a real gas versus hypothetical gases can vary quite a bit as pressures get into these levels, so there's some uncertainty about how do you correct for that. So we're have a number of experiments, tests going on in both of those years. But I would say it's, bottom line, it's still too early for us to have a good sense for what the recovery factor would be or what proper spacing would be and, in fact, what's really driving that the extreme productivity we're seeing.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then it's been a couple of quarters since you talked about the value of having both the upstream and midstream together and had previously commented that EQT's production growth rates slowed, EQM's third-party growth accelerate the synergies ha
componenttext: Great. And then it's been a couple of quarters since you talked about the value of having both the upstream and midstream together and had previously commented that EQT's production growth rates slowed, EQM's third-party growth accelerate the synergies having the 2 units together has reduced. Just wondering in the past year and looking out to 2017 as growth does slow, has your view on the magnitude of these synergies changed at all? Or are they still great as they were in 2015?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Directionally, this is David, they're still about  the same. My view all along is there's always going to be pressures pulling apart 2 groups that have cash flow that have different attributes. But I think in this environment, we're actually seeing more o
componenttext: Directionally, this is David, they're still about  the same. My view all along is there's always going to be pressures pulling apart 2 groups that have cash flow that have different attributes. But I think in this environment, we're actually seeing more of the synergies between the upstream and the midstream than we probably would've expected a couple of years ago. And I'm thinking particularly about some of the pipeline projects. But then also kind of going back to the Utica, we do believe that it's still likely that we'd want a somewhat dedicated, at least, Midstream business for the Utica. And of course, we're taking a look at what that might look like, at least, let's say, upstream of the first compressor station. And to be able to coordinate the development of the upstream and the development of the midstream is a benefit that we have that we don't think is available to those who are just pure-play on one side or the other. And frankly, on the FERC regulator pipeline, I think you see a disconnect in some circumstances between what the pipelines are saying and what the producer shippers are saying, and you don't see that with us. So I think that's another case where the -- having the synergies between the upstream and the midstream works to create value over time for the EQT shareholder.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then you talked about last quarter, nat gas price being 3 50 and wanted to quickly respond to higher prices. Strips up moved up $0.20, $0.30 since that call, but it does feel like your plan 2017 fundamentals are improving. So the question is, i
componenttext: Great. And then you talked about last quarter, nat gas price being 3 50 and wanted to quickly respond to higher prices. Strips up moved up $0.20, $0.30 since that call, but it does feel like your plan 2017 fundamentals are improving. So the question is, is 3 50 a clearing price that would trigger EQT to increase activity? Or would it be lower again that you're a low-cost producer? And given the historical 9 months by the sales time, is there a way to more quickly respond to higher prices?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The ability to more quickly respond to both directions are certainly something that we're looking at. But I wouldn't say that we are at a point now where the prices are where we would want them to be. I mean, it's -- to use the analogy that a lot of us ha
componenttext: The ability to more quickly respond to both directions are certainly something that we're looking at. But I wouldn't say that we are at a point now where the prices are where we would want them to be. I mean, it's -- to use the analogy that a lot of us have used that there's a light at the end of the tunnel, and we're a little more confident that it's not attached to the front of a train. But I don't know that we want to be going all in on that possibility.

componenttext: I'll provide a little bit of comment. Steve might want to provide a comment, too. For the most part, we happen to be focused on transactions that are relatively small in nature. They're not public company transactions. That's just the nature of what happens to be out there. And we do still think that it makes sense for us to be cognizant of the credit risk when we look at those acquisitions. And I guess maybe I'll just leave it at that. And frankly, it is more beneficial on the midstream side than the upstream. I think we've seen plenty of peers that have lower credit ratings than us, and I don't think -- I mean, just a little bit lower some investment-grade. It doesn't -- I think you could easily argue, it doesn't hurt them. But on the midstream side, I think to have a seat at the table and I do see a lot of opportunities maybe even more opportunities than we would have before with the changes in the macroenvironment and how it's affecting a lot of the other companies out there, I'd still think it's valuable to, in this environment, to maintain that investment-grade rating and soon assume that we will behave in a manner that is consistent with that view. And Steve, do you want to provide any more thoughts on what you're seeing on the M&A?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add really, probably reiterate points Dave has already made, but focus mostly on asset packages. We have a very narrow core area that we think is interesting. So the things that are interesting to us are asset packages that fit nice
componenttext: The only thing I would add really, probably reiterate points Dave has already made, but focus mostly on asset packages. We have a very narrow core area that we think is interesting. So the things that are interesting to us are asset packages that fit nicely with our existing upstream and midstream assets where, as Dave said, we get those true synergies. And I think there's a number of those packages out there right now, some are on the market, some were just in discussions with their directly with companies. So we're looking at a lot of stuff. We're really hoping to find things where we have more synergies than our competitors, which allows us to be competitive on price, yet get it at a price that still leaves a lot of value for our shareholders. So in this environment, there seems to be several opportunities that are interesting, and we continue to pursue them. But if the prices aren't right, we won't do it.

componenttext: Maybe a question for Steve. Steve, you talked about bringing those cost down in those Utica wells. I'm just wondering, how do you balance the completion optimizations? headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think our thought process on that is, we're definitely trying to figure out how to get the cost down with the idea of what the ongoing development mode cost would be. But to the extent that we need to run some experiments or gather data to get a b
componenttext: Well, I think our thought process on that is, we're definitely trying to figure out how to get the cost down with the idea of what the ongoing development mode cost would be. But to the extent that we need to run some experiments or gather data to get a better understanding of the reservoir, at this point, sorry, the nature of the effort is kind of a science project still at this point or more expiratory nature. We're very willing to make those investments. And we understand that those are not intended to be ongoing types of cost. Those are onetime cost to cut the cord, to get a specialty law, to run some sort of reservoir test. I don't think we're going -- that will get in the way. We're certainly not avoiding gathering necessary data in order to get any single wells cost below some artificial threshold.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on your comment on ceramic and just potential superiority or improving performance in the Utica. Can you talk a little bit more about the reasons for why this may be? And then also, is there -- is it something that's unique to the Ut
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on your comment on ceramic and just potential superiority or improving performance in the Utica. Can you talk a little bit more about the reasons for why this may be? And then also, is there -- is it something that's unique to the Utica section? Or do you see the potential for further completion efficiency improvement using ceramic in the Marcellus as well?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, I think it's -- we believe that if ceramic is a driver in productivity, which at this point is still an unknown, but it's one clear variable between the wells. We don't think it would apply to the Marcellus. The real driver behind the ceramic and r
componenttext: Brian, I think it's -- we believe that if ceramic is a driver in productivity, which at this point is still an unknown, but it's one clear variable between the wells. We don't think it would apply to the Marcellus. The real driver behind the ceramic and recently the one with the first well is at these depths with the stresses we're dealing with, the strength of the sand we use is we're pushing the upper limit of it. We did some laboratory testing of the sand that suggested it should be okay, which is why we switched on the second and third well. But the results we're seeing indicate that potentially it's a problem. It's mostly due to crushing and/or embedment of the sand into the shale, mostly crushing that we are concerned about. So the ceramic proppant has a higher crush strength, and we think that's not a problem. Again, we're not certain that it is a problem with sand, but that's an obvious variable between the Scotts Run and the other wells, and the cost differential has been cut nearly in half. We thought it was wise to go back and see how much productivity difference that's driving.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you think the cost differential is secular or because of the decline in activity, particularly for ceramic elsewhere?
componenttext: Do you think the cost differential is secular or because of the decline in activity, particularly for ceramic elsewhere?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we'll be able to maintain that cost advantage. We actually got that by talking to a second ceramic provider, and the primary provider or the provider on the Scotts Run then did come in with a much better price. I think we've got some competition i
componenttext: I think we'll be able to maintain that cost advantage. We actually got that by talking to a second ceramic provider, and the primary provider or the provider on the Scotts Run then did come in with a much better price. I think we've got some competition in the space now. And I think if Deep Utica full development mode kind of kicks in, in the basin, there'll be enough demand for them to justify getting the ceramic up here. So I expect it will be able to hold on to that.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then shifting more a little bit to production and the macro. you talked in the past about the lead time from when EQT's rig activity and CapEx activity comes down to when you would actually see the production impact. I think you talked about it
componenttext: Great. And then shifting more a little bit to production and the macro. you talked in the past about the lead time from when EQT's rig activity and CapEx activity comes down to when you would actually see the production impact. I think you talked about it being kind of 9 months plus, which is probably why the production stayed strong, relatively strong this year. Can you just provide any updates on that lead time whether it's shrinking or expanding? And then to the degree that you ramp-up or decide to recommit capital, does that work on the other direction as well? Or there will be that would suggest we will see the production response with a shorter lead time?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think Brian, when we do our modeling, with our current process of how we drill and complete the wells, the 9 months is a pretty good average. Smaller pads, shorter laterals end up being shorter. Bigger pads take longer. We have done some optimizat
componenttext: Well, I think Brian, when we do our modeling, with our current process of how we drill and complete the wells, the 9 months is a pretty good average. Smaller pads, shorter laterals end up being shorter. Bigger pads take longer. We have done some optimization modeling of that to see what we could do to shorten it up. And we do have some options where, if we had the right economic incentives, we could spend a little bit more money primarily on more rig moves. So we've moved the rig more often and get wells online quicker that again, it would be based on the forward curve and what we thought the prices were going to do so whether it be worth spending the extra money. But we do have a plan in plays where we could shorten that up probably maybe the 5 or 6 months might be the best we can get to try and capture and improve the commodity market if we saw that happening.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is Dave. If we look at the market more broadly, we actually think there could be factors that could lengthen that lag time for a number of companies. I mean, if you've gotten rid of some of your land people, for instance, and you can get permits
componenttext: And this is Dave. If we look at the market more broadly, we actually think there could be factors that could lengthen that lag time for a number of companies. I mean, if you've gotten rid of some of your land people, for instance, and you can get permits as easily, some of the rigs that have been laid down and maybe they've been cannibalized for parts, crews that kind of wandered off -- it's one of the reasons we've tried to remain a little bit more consistent in our activity levels so that we would be better positioned for that. So I have a feeling that the rest of the market may actually see longer lead times at the early stages of a ramp-up, assuming prices move up enough to justify such a ramp-up at some point in the future.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So the market will have some struggle with this. EQT is a little bit better positioned, if not very well positioned in your mind to not have issue?
componenttext: Got it. So the market will have some struggle with this. EQT is a little bit better positioned, if not very well positioned in your mind to not have issue?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and look, there maybe other peers who are in somewhat similar situation to us. But we think the market at large is probably -- I think the market and large is going to have a longer lead times. And EQT and probably a handful of other companies would
componenttext: Yes, and look, there maybe other peers who are in somewhat similar situation to us. But we think the market at large is probably -- I think the market and large is going to have a longer lead times. And EQT and probably a handful of other companies would not be subject to some of those issues.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Hanold from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Hanold from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, I was wondering, you all indicated that the third well, I guess the BIG-190, had similar results to padded well, if I understood your comments correctly. Is there any number you can kind of provide on what some of the initial relative productivity
componenttext: Steve, I was wondering, you all indicated that the third well, I guess the BIG-190, had similar results to padded well, if I understood your comments correctly. Is there any number you can kind of provide on what some of the initial relative productivity was in some of the back pressure data that? And then also just to get a sense of how you all are progressing on the cost side of things. What is the cost on the 190 look like it came in at? And what's the AFE on this next one, the shipment well you would be drilling.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott, I'm not provide to prepared to provide any specific details on the BIG-190 yet in terms of productivity. On the cost side, it came in normalized for a 5,400-foot lateral. It came in, I think, just $100,00 or $200,000 above the $14 million uppe
componenttext: Yes, Scott, I'm not provide to prepared to provide any specific details on the BIG-190 yet in terms of productivity. On the cost side, it came in normalized for a 5,400-foot lateral. It came in, I think, just $100,00 or $200,000 above the $14 million upper end of our range. We expect the shipment well to come in within that range and below $14 million, excluding some of the science we're going to do on well. So Neal asked earlier, we are cutting the core on the shipment wells, so there'll be some extra cost there. But if you excluded that, we expect the shipment well to be within the range. Then things like the dissolvable frac plugs, if that works, we can implemented in future wells across the whole well. That's roughly $700,000 savings that we haven't factored in yet. So very, very confident that we're going to be in the midpoint of that range voer the next few wells and with still lots of opportunity to for improvement. So I think over time, feeling pretty good about the bottom end of that range.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just to clarify, so the rig on $14 million per shipment includes the cost of ceramics but doesn't include dissolvable plug benefit?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just to clarify, so the rig on $14 million per shipment includes the cost of ceramics but doesn't include dissolvable plug benefit?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. Okay. And then BIG-190, how long has that been online now?
componenttext: That's great. Okay. And then BIG-190, how long has that been online now?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't remember. Maybe 1 month, 1.5 months.
componenttext: Well, I don't remember. Maybe 1 month, 1.5 months.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And then really quickly, looking at hedging. What is big picture like when you look at the forward curve? Where's the level where you all feel like more comfortable layering hedges? And would you do it more to just protect the downside? Or how
componenttext: Okay, okay. And then really quickly, looking at hedging. What is big picture like when you look at the forward curve? Where's the level where you all feel like more comfortable layering hedges? And would you do it more to just protect the downside? Or how did that strategy for you guys look going forward?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we do take a portfolio approach. There's no doubt. When the price is below what we think is the economic clearing price, we tend to be more at the low end of the target range that we have. And when the price is above that, we're more at the high end
componenttext: Well, we do take a portfolio approach. There's no doubt. When the price is below what we think is the economic clearing price, we tend to be more at the low end of the target range that we have. And when the price is above that, we're more at the high end. So now I'd say we're probably a little bit more, as we think about it not for '16 but as you look beyond it, we'd still be layering hedges in, but we'd be staying more of the low end of what our target range would be. And again, I think the difficulty is going to be -- since I do believe prices are going to move past that, that economic clearing price to be disciplined about moving up to the top as opposed to getting caught up with kind of the opposite of the current, if you will, the press feeling in the market that we've seen it before where gets you [indiscernible] Incidentally, when you talk about the current year, we have tended to view that as just being a standard commercial activity. So we let our commercial group make decision to about the things that they want to do in year to take advantage of some of the opportunities that they see. We don't really view that as hedging so much as just normal commercial activity.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then typically, are you going to target -- and I think, correct me if I'm wrong, you typically like to utilize swaps? Is that right?
componenttext: Okay. And then typically, are you going to target -- and I think, correct me if I'm wrong, you typically like to utilize swaps? Is that right?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, but that's just because the way market is going. We're certainly not the opposed to using instruments rather on their own or embedded in the sale of a physical commodity. It's just all depends on what the market looks like. So you don't want to be bu
componenttext: Yes, but that's just because the way market is going. We're certainly not the opposed to using instruments rather on their own or embedded in the sale of a physical commodity. It's just all depends on what the market looks like. So you don't want to be buying a lot of options if it's volatile. You'd rather sell them, right, so that you'd say, well, we're not going to buy floors if it's a -- if it's expensive to do, so you tend to go more flops and vice versa. So it's much more market conditions, I'd say. It's not a philosophical view that we should be using swaps as opposed to options or as opposed to colors.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just have some 2 bigger picture questions as I try to figure out realized pricing for the -- for your E&P segment going forward. In recent weeks, we've heard a number of pipeline projects out of the Marcellus getting delayed due to the regulatory proces
componenttext: I just have some 2 bigger picture questions as I try to figure out realized pricing for the -- for your E&P segment going forward. In recent weeks, we've heard a number of pipeline projects out of the Marcellus getting delayed due to the regulatory process or being canceled altogether. Can you talk about what you think this spillover effects from this will be with respect to basis differential beyond '16, especially with the cross current of production starting to roll over and maybe NYMEX prices going up, potential opportunities for your projects and what this all ultimately mean for the production outlook in the Marcellus, Utica?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Christine, this is Randy. Certainly that the -- in the Marcellus and Uticad, we're really talking about the rate of growth slowing, so there has certainly been continuing growth and the facts are there have been infrastructure projects that are bein
componenttext: Well, Christine, this is Randy. Certainly that the -- in the Marcellus and Uticad, we're really talking about the rate of growth slowing, so there has certainly been continuing growth and the facts are there have been infrastructure projects that are being delayed. So in the bigger picture, as you asked in terms of EQT, I think we're very well positioned. The fact is that we have a broad portfolio of upstream capacity, and we have the Ohio Valley Connector project that is in the currently in construction that we anticipate or expect to come online at the end of this year, which will tie into our capacity and improve our pricing from that standpoint. Now from the midstream perspective, obviously, as we have been playing out these projects and build out our hub and are executing accordingly, we think that obviously increases the value of those assets over the long term and even in the short term. So I think, certainly, as other projects are challenged, we think we're very well positioned to continue to grow and to improve our realized pricing at EQT.

componenttext: And then just on that in your presentation, your slide for the Marcellus capacity stops at first quarter '18. Or do you take all of it day 1 and then you release whatever capacity you're not you using on a short-term basis while you grow into it, which I think is what you historically done? Can you just remind us how that works?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, when MVP comes online, as the capacity obligations are do not ramp-up, they start at that time. Having said that, we have the option to continue to keep all of the capacity and to grow into it. We also have a variety of explorations on other transpo
componenttext: Sure, when MVP comes online, as the capacity obligations are do not ramp-up, they start at that time. Having said that, we have the option to continue to keep all of the capacity and to grow into it. We also have a variety of explorations on other transportation contracts. So it provides us the flexibility, if you will, to reconfigure that portfolio at the time that the MVP comes on or to maintain all of the capacity at the time we want where we needed for continued growth. So as we positioned our portfolio with the anticipation of MVP coming on, we have a variety of different expirations on the upstream pipeline that allow us the flexibility to really optimize that portfolio.

componenttext: Yes. I've got a bigger-picture question. The stock at the EQT level trades at a pretty meaningful discount to your Appalachian peers. headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Dave. And so I do agree with your premise, and it is difficult at this point to differentiate between a couple of factors that might both be a work. One of them is that conglomerate issue that we chatted about before different investors for midstr
componenttext: This is Dave. And so I do agree with your premise, and it is difficult at this point to differentiate between a couple of factors that might both be a work. One of them is that conglomerate issue that we chatted about before different investors for midstream and upstream, that is certainly a possibility. And I think we all know the best way to go about resolving that kind of issue over time. And then the other, I think, possibility is that people look at the EQGP price and they aren't sure given the relative lack of float with that's a good marker to be using for the midstream value at EQT. And I think we also been pretty clear that we've got the notion over time having more flow out there is going to be a way to get my confidence level. That's going on. Now I also happen to think that EQGP, although I noticed that it's now trading after the whole market has been -- haven't had a tough period since its IPO almost a year ago, is now trading just a little bit above its, just above its IPO price. I still think the that represents a discount on EQGP. And I believe and I think I've said this before that I fear that some of that is just on kind of a sticker -- like a reverse sticker shock that folks models on growth, et cetera, would have suggested higher valuation for EQGP, but the current field this still that falls out of those calculation just relatively low number. And there's a concern about bidding it the price up such that, that current deal drops too much. But I think as we continue to see distribution increases announced consistent with our guidance at EQGP level, that will tend to go away, and that aspect of revaluation discount will start to be dealt with. But as far some of those other issues that I mentioned, we do work through those issues. We do see it same way that you do, and we're kind of working through our alternatives on how to make sure that our shareholders realize that full value.

componenttext: Yes, right now, the plan is still 5, but the actual number we end up drilling in the year is going to be very much based on the results we're seeing. And we want to be very careful about not getting ahead of our science nor getting ahead of our ability to take the gas away and get it to a market. But we also want to progress our understanding and start to make some decisions about what the development mode of Utica might look like. So I think for sure, we're going to get the shipment well frac which we're currently tracking that get results from it. It will give us a lot of information on the impact of ceramic proppant. We'll get some information on use of their dissolvable plug, so you might be able to take another step forward in our estimation of cost and, therefore, economics. So it's going to be kind of a decide-as-we-go kind of approach, I think. But certainly, don't expect to be making any decisions before mid to late summer in terms of in sort of a ramp-up.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the EQT Corporation First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Pat Kane, Chief Investor Relations Officer.
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the EQT Corporation First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Pat Kane, Chief Investor Relations Officer. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Adam. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in EQT Corporation's Conference Call. With me today are Dave Porges, Chief Executive Officer; Steve Schlotterbeck, President of EQT and President of Exploration and Production; Randy
componenttext:
Thanks, Adam. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in EQT Corporation's Conference Call. 
With me today are Dave Porges, Chief Executive Officer; Steve Schlotterbeck, President of EQT and President of Exploration and Production; Randy Crawford, Senior Vice President of EQT and President of Midstream and Commercial; and Rob McNally, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
This call would be replayed for a 7-day period beginning at approximately 1:30 p.m. Eastern today. The telephone number for the replay is (201) 612-7415. The confirmation code is 13634047. The call will also be replayed for 7 days on our website. 
To remind you, the results of EQT Midstream Partners, ticker EQM; and EQGP Holdings, ticker EQGP, are consolidated in EQT's results. Earlier this morning, there was a separate joint press release issued by EQM and EQGP. The partnerships will have a joint earnings conference call at 10:30 a.m. today, which requires that we take the last question at 11:20 this morning. The dial-in number for that call is (201) 689-7817. 
In a moment, Rob will summarize EQT's first quarter 2016 results. Next, Steve will give a Utica update. And finally, David will discuss certain market and strategic matters. Following the prepared remarks, David, Steve, Randy and Rob will all be available to answer your questions. 
But first, I'd like to remind you that today's call may contain forward-looking statements. You can find factors that could cause the company's actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements listed in today's press release and other risk factors in EQT's Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015, as updated by any subsequent Form 10-Qs, which are on file with the SEC and available on our website. 
Today's call may also contain certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to this morning's press release for important disclosures regarding such measures, including reconciliations of most comparable GAAP financial measures. 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Robert McNally.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pat. Before we begin the Q1 result, I want to review changes to our press reconciliation and production segment page. Historically, we presented the cost of gathering and transporting are gas as revenue deductions on the price reconciliation in
componenttext:
Thank you, Pat. Before we begin the Q1 result, I want to review changes to our press reconciliation and production segment page. Historically, we presented the cost of gathering and transporting are gas as revenue deductions on the price reconciliation in production segment page. Starting today, gathering, transmission and processing costs are not reported as expenses on the production segment page. The exception is the transportation charges for capacity not used to transport EQT produced gas, which is either resold or used to transport purchased gas by our marketing group is still presented as a revenue offset in accordance with GAAP. The new net marketing services line on the production segment page includes these costs as well as the related recoveries, both of which are now excluded from the price reconciliation. Previously, this capacity cost, which were $0.23 per Mcf for the first quarter of 2016, were reported as a third-party gathering and transmission cost on the price reconciliation; while the marketing recoveries, which were $0.26 per Mcf this quarter were presented as a component of recoveries included in the average differential. The main change to guidance that you will see is that our differential guidance went from negative $0.40 to $0.50 per Mcf for 2016 to negative $0.60 to $0.70 per Mcf. Offsetting this change to reported differential is a change in our guidance to third-party gathering and transmission expense from $0.50 per Mcf for the year to $0.30 per Mcf. So netting these 2 charges, necessitated by the change in reporting format, is effectively a reiteration of our previous guidance. 
We posted the historic price reconciliation for the first quarter and the 2015 results by quarter using the new format on our website. Finally, we have also posted our updated 2016 guidance conforming to the new format. 
Now for an update on the remaining drop-down. We are currently working through the internal process, which includes all the necessary accounting, legal and commercial work. We expect the drop-down to occur in the second half of the year. As we've mentioned in the past, there's about $40 million of EBITDA to be dropped down and expect the value to be up to $300 million. As Pat mention, EQGP Holdings and EQT Midstream Partners results are consolidated in EQT Corporation's results. In this morning's release, we added a table for that calculation of net income attributable to noncontrolling interest. EQT recorded $82.8 million of net income attributable to noncontrolling interest in the first quarter of 2016 as compared to $47.7 million in the first quarter of 2015. We currently forecast $77 million of net income attributable to noncontrolling interest for the second quarter of 2016 and $320 million for the full year assuming the midpoint of EQM's guidance. 
I will now provide a brief overview of the first quarter results. As you read in the press release this morning, EQT announced first quarter 2016 adjusted earnings per diluted share of $0.07 compared to $1.07 in the first quarter of 2015. Adjusted operating cash flow attributable to EQT decreased to $156 million as compared to $218.6 million in the first quarter of 2015. The high level in history for the first quarter was strong volume growth and a lower commodity price environment with another very solid operational quarter, including record produce natural gas sales and record gathering volumes of midstream. With the exception of $3.8 million restructuring charge, the first quarter was very straightforward, so I'll keep my remarks fairly brief. 
The story at EQT Production continues to be the growth in sales of produced natural gas. Production sales volume of 179.9 Bcfe in the recently completed quarter was 24% higher than the first quarter of 2015 and 16% higher than the fourth quarter of 2015. As discussed, the lower average realized price more than offset the volume growth. The realized price was $2.63 per Mcfe compared to $4.06 per Mcfe in the first quarter of last year. You'll find the detailed components of price in the tables in this morning's press release. 
Net marketing services revenue totaled $4.6 million in the first quarter of 2016, $8.6 million lower than the same quarter last year due to incremental capacity cost in the current quarter and colder weather in 2015. Total operating expenses at EQT Production were $489.3 million or 7% higher quarter-over-quarter. DD&A, gathering, transmission and processing expenses were all higher, consistent with the significant production growth although production taxes were lower for the quarter as a result of lower prices. 
Moving on to Midstream results. Operating income here was $141.9 million, 9% higher than the first quarter of 2015. Operating revenue was $224.7 million, $16.5 million in the first quarter of last year as a result of higher Marcellus volumes. Total operating expenses were $82.9 million, $4.4 million higher quarter-over-quarter as a result of our continuing growth in the Midstream business. 
And then finally, our standard liquidity update. We closed the quarter in a great liquidity position with 0 net short-term debt outstanding under EQT's $1.5 billion unsecured revolver and about $1.6 billion of cash on the balance sheet, which is clearly cash on hand at EQM and EQGP. We currently forecast $600 million to $650 million at operating cash flow for 2016 at EQT, which includes approximately $150 million of distributions to EQT from EQGP. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Steve.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rob. My focus today is to provide an update on our deep Utica program. Our 2 objectives for 2016 are to get our cost per well down to our target range of between $12.5 million and $14 million per well and to achieve consistent well results in l
componenttext:
Thank you, Rob. My focus today is to provide an update on our deep Utica program. Our 2 objectives for 2016 are to get our cost per well down to our target range of between $12.5 million and $14 million per well and to achieve consistent well results in line with the median of wells drilled into deep Utica well by EQT and our peers so far. 
For the Utica to compete with capital with Marcellus, we're targeting EURs approximately 75% higher than our core Marcellus wells. The higher EUR per well, combined with the higher percentage of the EU are being produced in the first few years and lower expected gathering compression cost, should provide returns competitive with the Marcellus. We currently have 3 wells producing, the Scotts Run and padded wells in Greene County, Pennsylvania and the BIG-190 well in Wetzel County, West Virginia. This Scotts Run well began declining at the end of March after producing at a flat rate of 30 million cubic feet per day since July of 2015, which was a total of 244 days. The decline is in line with our expectations, and our EUR estimate for this well is currently 20 Bcf or approximately 6 Bcf per 1,000 foot of lateral. The results of the padded and Big 190 wells were not as strong as our Scotts Run well or in line with what we are seeing from other wells in the area. It is too early to calculate an EUR for these 2 wells. 
The shipment well was spud in January and is currently being fracked while the West Run well was spud in April. After West Run, we plan to move back to West Virginia to drill another well in Wetzel County, probably be called the Big 177. We used ceramic [indiscernible] on the Scotts Run and achieved superior results compared to the padded and BIG-190 wells, which used sand as the profit. It is not clear that the prop and difference explains the result, but we decided to use ceramic prop in the next 3 completions, including the shipment, to determine that the prop and type has an impact on well productivity. The good news is, we have negotiated a 40% reduction in the price of ceramic profit since the Scotts Run well. For a typical 5,400-foot lateral, the incremental cost of using ceramics versus sand is now $1.4 million per well compared to about $2.5 million incrementally at the time we drilled the Scotts Run. 
On the cost side, we continue to see significant improvement. Drilling cost continue to come down as we gain experience and improve the techniques and equipment used to drill these wells. On the completion side, we will be testing the plug technology for the first time on the shipment well. We estimate that this technology will save us an additional $700,000 per well if successful. Our team continues to safely reduce the cost of these wells and is confident we can achieve our target well cost even with ceramic prop. We will continue to provide quarterly updates on our progress on the Deep Utica, and I'll now turn the call over to Dave.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. I would like to briefly provide 2 updates and 1 other comment on today's call. The first update is to my comments in our February call regarding rig count as a leading indicator of production. At that time, there were 246 gas equivalent
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. I would like to briefly provide 2 updates and 1 other comment on today's call. The first update is to my comments in our February call regarding rig count as a leading indicator of production. At that time, there were 246 gas equivalent rigs, down from the stable level of 700 to 800 that prevailed from about mid-2012 through the end of 2014. Since that February call, the gas equivalent rig count declined by another 29% to 174 gas equivalent rigs today. This means we are now down 57% in the past year and 76% since the end of 2014. We are beginning to see what appear to be some signs of a supply reduction as a pro-U.S. gas production is about 2 Bcf per day lower than the February peak. While those 2014 rig count probably represented far too much development activity, the plateauing and beginning of a decline in production suggest that our thesis of higher future natural gas prices still looks just as solid, even though we confess that the timing of any meaningful price increases continues to be uncertain. 
Given our capital strength and the fact that we have not had to make dramatic reductions in staff, we continue to be well positioned comparatively to adjusted development plans should higher prices materialize. I do personally continue to believe that the eventual price increase will likely eventually overshoot the equilibrium price necessarily to balance supply with demand, but that just means we will have to be as disciplined in a more constructive economic environment as we have been in the current less-than-constructive economic environment. 
On a related update, we continue to look to add to our core acreage position but have not yet announced any transactions. The good news is that there are many high-quality asset packages being marketed in our core focus area. Along those lines, so that we do not have to break with our practice of not commenting on specific transactions, we wanted to provide some insight into the types of assets that we are examining. If you look at our website, for a hard copy of our most recent investment presentations, you will see a pretty clearly delineated version of our core area, all of which is in the southwestern portion of the Marcellus play. If you become aware of opportunities that are largely or entirely within our core, you can safely assume that we are looking or have looked at the opportunity. You can equally safely assume that we are not looking at and interested at looking at opportunities that lie outside our core area, again as defined by that rectangle in our current investor presentation. 
To expand on that somewhat, we further look closely at the number of drilling locations and potential feed of 10 [ph] those locations that represent a combination of EQT's existing acreage and development opportunities and those provided by the target. True synergies, if you will. My final comment pertains to an area of financial risk that I've focused on early in my time at EQT, my philosophical objection to shareholders barring the investment risk of employees portfolios via defined-benefit pension plans. The pension benefit obligation was about $150 million when I arrived at EQT, those many years ago, and was forecast to be multiples higher than that within a decade. As a result, I wanted to reduce the extent of the associated investment risk. We set about strengthening the plan over the years, and as a result, we were able to apply for and just recently received approval to finally terminate the remaining vestiges of the plan altogether. There will be a modest charge recorded possibly as soon as the second quarter, but we will have finally brought that obligation and the risk associated with it down to 0. 
In summary, EQT is committed to increasing the value of your shares. We look forward to continuing to execute on our commitment to our shareholders and appreciate your continued support. 
And with that, I'd like to turn the call back over to Pat Kane.

componenttextpreview: Phil, this is Steve. I think we're still exploring that, so it is still a fairly anomalous well in terms of how productive it's been. So clearly, there's really 2 areas of focus, one is the size of the drainage area size or the size of the box that we're
componenttext: Phil, this is Steve. I think we're still exploring that, so it is still a fairly anomalous well in terms of how productive it's been. So clearly, there's really 2 areas of focus, one is the size of the drainage area size or the size of the box that we're drawing from. Since it's a reservoir we don't have a lot of experience with yet, I think there's still a lot of uncertainty about what the right drainage area is. And then there's still some questions about basically the density of the gas and the reservoir, so how much can fit inside a given box at these fairly extreme pressures we're dealing with. So without getting too technical, the behavior of a real gas versus hypothetical gases can vary quite a bit as pressures get into these levels, so there's some uncertainty about how do you correct for that. So we're have a number of experiments, tests going on in both of those years. But I would say it's, bottom line, it's still too early for us to have a good sense for what the recovery factor would be or what proper spacing would be and, in fact, what's really driving that the extreme productivity we're seeing.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then it's been a couple of quarters since you talked about the value of having both the upstream and midstream together and had previously commented that EQT's production growth rates slowed, EQM's third-party growth accelerate the synergies ha
componenttext: Great. And then it's been a couple of quarters since you talked about the value of having both the upstream and midstream together and had previously commented that EQT's production growth rates slowed, EQM's third-party growth accelerate the synergies having the 2 units together has reduced. Just wondering in the past year and looking out to 2017 as growth does slow, has your view on the magnitude of these synergies changed at all? Or are they still great as they were in 2015?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Directionally, this is David, they're still about  the same. My view all along is there's always going to be pressures pulling apart 2 groups that have cash flow that have different attributes. But I think in this environment, we're actually seeing more o
componenttext: Directionally, this is David, they're still about  the same. My view all along is there's always going to be pressures pulling apart 2 groups that have cash flow that have different attributes. But I think in this environment, we're actually seeing more of the synergies between the upstream and the midstream than we probably would've expected a couple of years ago. And I'm thinking particularly about some of the pipeline projects. But then also kind of going back to the Utica, we do believe that it's still likely that we'd want a somewhat dedicated, at least, Midstream business for the Utica. And of course, we're taking a look at what that might look like, at least, let's say, upstream of the first compressor station. And to be able to coordinate the development of the upstream and the development of the midstream is a benefit that we have that we don't think is available to those who are just pure-play on one side or the other. And frankly, on the FERC regulator pipeline, I think you see a disconnect in some circumstances between what the pipelines are saying and what the producer shippers are saying, and you don't see that with us. So I think that's another case where the -- having the synergies between the upstream and the midstream works to create value over time for the EQT shareholder.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then you talked about last quarter, nat gas price being 3 50 and wanted to quickly respond to higher prices. Strips up moved up $0.20, $0.30 since that call, but it does feel like your plan 2017 fundamentals are improving. So the question is, i
componenttext: Great. And then you talked about last quarter, nat gas price being 3 50 and wanted to quickly respond to higher prices. Strips up moved up $0.20, $0.30 since that call, but it does feel like your plan 2017 fundamentals are improving. So the question is, is 3 50 a clearing price that would trigger EQT to increase activity? Or would it be lower again that you're a low-cost producer? And given the historical 9 months by the sales time, is there a way to more quickly respond to higher prices?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The ability to more quickly respond to both directions are certainly something that we're looking at. But I wouldn't say that we are at a point now where the prices are where we would want them to be. I mean, it's -- to use the analogy that a lot of us ha
componenttext: The ability to more quickly respond to both directions are certainly something that we're looking at. But I wouldn't say that we are at a point now where the prices are where we would want them to be. I mean, it's -- to use the analogy that a lot of us have used that there's a light at the end of the tunnel, and we're a little more confident that it's not attached to the front of a train. But I don't know that we want to be going all in on that possibility.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Dave, first question, I appreciate the comments on the M&A without talking about specifics. Just kind of curious if you can comment on the size of deals, the quantities of deals as and then how you balance that versus keeping the investment-grade rating?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll provide a little bit of comment. Steve might want to provide a comment, too. For the most part, we happen to be focused on transactions that are relatively small in nature. They're not public company transactions. That's just the nature of what happe
componenttext: I'll provide a little bit of comment. Steve might want to provide a comment, too. For the most part, we happen to be focused on transactions that are relatively small in nature. They're not public company transactions. That's just the nature of what happens to be out there. And we do still think that it makes sense for us to be cognizant of the credit risk when we look at those acquisitions. And I guess maybe I'll just leave it at that. And frankly, it is more beneficial on the midstream side than the upstream. I think we've seen plenty of peers that have lower credit ratings than us, and I don't think -- I mean, just a little bit lower some investment-grade. It doesn't -- I think you could easily argue, it doesn't hurt them. But on the midstream side, I think to have a seat at the table and I do see a lot of opportunities maybe even more opportunities than we would have before with the changes in the macroenvironment and how it's affecting a lot of the other companies out there, I'd still think it's valuable to, in this environment, to maintain that investment-grade rating and soon assume that we will behave in a manner that is consistent with that view. And Steve, do you want to provide any more thoughts on what you're seeing on the M&A?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add really, probably reiterate points Dave has already made, but focus mostly on asset packages. We have a very narrow core area that we think is interesting. So the things that are interesting to us are asset packages that fit nice
componenttext: The only thing I would add really, probably reiterate points Dave has already made, but focus mostly on asset packages. We have a very narrow core area that we think is interesting. So the things that are interesting to us are asset packages that fit nicely with our existing upstream and midstream assets where, as Dave said, we get those true synergies. And I think there's a number of those packages out there right now, some are on the market, some were just in discussions with their directly with companies. So we're looking at a lot of stuff. We're really hoping to find things where we have more synergies than our competitors, which allows us to be competitive on price, yet get it at a price that still leaves a lot of value for our shareholders. So in this environment, there seems to be several opportunities that are interesting, and we continue to pursue them. But if the prices aren't right, we won't do it.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Maybe a question for Steve. Steve, you talked about bringing those cost down in those Utica wells. I'm just wondering, how do you balance the completion optimizations? I know you guys have certainly done some exciting things there. How do you think about sort of balancing that and some enhancements there while at the same time bringing the cost down? Just kind of what sort of levers you're pulling there?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think our thought process on that is, we're definitely trying to figure out how to get the cost down with the idea of what the ongoing development mode cost would be. But to the extent that we need to run some experiments or gather data to get a b
componenttext: Well, I think our thought process on that is, we're definitely trying to figure out how to get the cost down with the idea of what the ongoing development mode cost would be. But to the extent that we need to run some experiments or gather data to get a better understanding of the reservoir, at this point, sorry, the nature of the effort is kind of a science project still at this point or more expiratory nature. We're very willing to make those investments. And we understand that those are not intended to be ongoing types of cost. Those are onetime cost to cut the cord, to get a specialty law, to run some sort of reservoir test. I don't think we're going -- that will get in the way. We're certainly not avoiding gathering necessary data in order to get any single wells cost below some artificial threshold.
